sp.p: Sir, miſs Richland is below.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: How unlucky! Detain her a moment. We muſt improve my good friend, little Mr. Flanigan's appearance firſt. Here, let Mr. Flanigan have a ſuit of my cloaths—quick—the brown and ſilver—Do you hear?

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: That your honour gave away to the begging gentleman that makes verſes, becauſe it was as good as new.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: The white and gold then.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: That, your honour, I made bold to ſell, becauſe it was good for nothing.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: Well, the firſt that comes to hand then. The blue and gold then. I believe Mr. Flanigan will look beſt in blue. [Exit Flanigan.

sp.speaker: BAILIFF.
sp.p:
Rabbit me, but little Flanigan will look well in any thing. Ah, if your honour knew that bit of fleſh as well as I do, you'd be perfectly in love with him.
There's not a prettier ſcout in the four counties after a ſhy-cock than he: ſcents like a hound; ſticks like a weazle. He was maſter of the ceremonies to the black queen of Morocco, when I took him to follow me. (Re-enter Flanigan.) Heh, ecod, I think he looks ſo well, that I don't care if I have a ſuit from the ſame place for myſelf.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: Well, well, I hear the lady coming. Dear Mr. Twitch, I beg you'll give your friend directions not to ſpeak. As for yourſelf, I know you will ſay nothing without being directed.

sp.speaker: BAILIFF.
sp.p: Never you fear me; I'll ſhew the lady that I have ſomething to ſay for myſelf as well as another. One man has one way of talking, and another man has another, that's all the difference between them.

div.stage: Enter MISS RICHLAND and her MAID.

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: You'll be ſurpriſed, ſir, with this viſit. But you know I'm yet to thank you for chuſing my little library.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: Thanks, madam, are unneceſſary; as it was I that was obliged by your commands. Chairs here. Two of my very good friends, Mr. Twitch and Mr. Flanigan. Pray, gentlemen, ſit without ceremony.

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: Who can theſe odd-looking men be! I fear it is as I was informed. It muſt be ſo. (Aſide.

sp.speaker: BAILIFF, after a pauſe.
sp.p: Pretty weather, very pretty weather for the time of the year, madam.

sp.speaker: FOLLOWER.
sp.p: Very good circuit weather in the country.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: You officers are generally favourites among the ladies. My friends, madam, have been upon very diſagreeable duty, I aſſure you. The fair ſhould, in ſome meaſure, recompence the toils of the brave!

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: Our officers do indeed deſerve every favour. The gentlemen are in the marine ſervice, I preſume, ſir?

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: Why, madam, they do—occaſionally ſerve in the fleet, madam. A dangerous ſervice!

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: I'm told ſo. And I own, it has often ſurpriſed me, that, while we have had ſo many inſtances of bravery there, we have had ſo few of wit at home to praiſe it.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: I grant, madam, that our poets have not written as our ſoldiers have fought; but they have done all they could, and Hawke or Amherſt could do no more.

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: I'm quite diſpleaſed when I ſee a fine ſubject ſpoiled by a dull writer.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: We ſhould not be ſo ſevere againſt dull writers, madam. It is ten to one, but the dulleſt writer exceeds the moſt rigid French critic who preſumes to deſpiſe him.

sp.speaker: FOLLOWER.
sp.p: Damn the French, the parle vous, and all that belongs to them.

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! honeſt Mr. Flanigan. A true Engliſh officer, madam; he's not contented with beating the French, but he will ſcold them too.

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: Yet, Mr. Honeywood, this does not convince me but that ſeverity in criticiſm is neceſſary. It was our firſt adopting the ſeverity of French taſte, that has brought them in turn to taſte us.

sp.speaker: BAILIFF.
sp.p: Taſte us! By the Lord, madam, they devour us. Give monſeers but a taſte, and I'll be damn'd but they come in for a bellyful.

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: Very extraordinary this.

sp.speaker: FOLLOWER.
sp.p: But very true. What makes the bread riſing? the parle vous that devour us. What makes the mutton fivepence a pound? the parle vous that eat it up. What makes the beer threepence-halfpenny a pot?—

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: Ah! the vulgar rogues; all will be out. (Aſide.) Right, gentlemen, very right, upon my word, and quite to the purpoſe. They draw a parallel, madam, between the mental taſte and that of our ſenſes. We are injured as much by French ſeverity in the one, as by French rapacity in the other. That's their meaning.

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: Tho' I don't ſee the force of the parallel, yet, I'll own, that we ſhould ſometimes pardon books, as we do our friends, that have now and then agreeable abfurdities to recommend them.

sp.speaker: BAILIFF.
sp.p: That's all my eye. The king only can pardon, as the law ſays: for, ſet in caſe—

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: I'm quite of your opinion, ſir. I ſee the whole drift of your argument. Yes, certainly, our preſuming to pardon any work, is arrogating a power that belongs to another. If all have power to condemn, what writer can be free?

sp.speaker: BAILIFF.
sp.p: By his habus corpus. His habus corpus can ſet him free at any time: for, ſet in caſe—

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: I'm obliged to you, ſir, for the hint. If, madam, as my friend obſerves, our laws are ſo careful of a gentleman's perſon, ſure we ought to be equally careful of his dearer part, his fame.

sp.speaker: FOLLOWER.
sp.p: Ay, but if ſo be a man's nabb'd, you know—

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: Mr. Flanigan, if you ſpoke for ever, you could not improve the laſt obſervation. For my own part, I think it concluſive.

sp.speaker: BAILIFF.
sp.p: As for the matter of that, mayhap—

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: Nay, ſir, give me leave in this inſtance to be poſitive. For, where is the neceſſity of cenſuring works without genius, which muſt ſhortly ſink of themſelves? what is it, but aiming our unneceſſary blow againſt a victim already under the hands of juſtice?

sp.speaker: BAILIFF.
sp.p: Juſtice! O, by the elevens, if you talk about juſtice, I think I am at home there: for, in a courſe of law—

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: My dear Mr. Twitch, I diſcern what you'd be at perfectly; and I believe the lady muſt be ſenſible of the art with which it is introduced. I ſuppoſe you perceive the meaning, madam, of his courſe of law.

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: I proteſt, ſir, I do not. I perceive only that you anſwer one gentleman before he has finiſhed, and the other before he has well begun.

sp.speaker: BAILIFF.
sp.p: Madam, you are a gentlewoman, and I will make the matter out. This here queſtion is about ſeverity and juſtice, and pardon, and the like of they. Now to explain the thing—

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: O! curſe your explanations. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: Mr. Leontine, ſir, below, deſires to ſpeak with you upon earneſt buſineſs.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: That's lucky. (Aſide.) Dear madam, you'll excuſe me and my good friends here, for a few minutes. There are books, madam, to amuſe you. Come, gentlemen, you know I make no ceremony with ſuch friends. After you, ſir. Excuſe me. Well, if I muſt. But I know your natural politeneſs.

sp.speaker: BAILIFF.
sp.p: Before and behind, you know.

sp.speaker: FOLLOWER.
sp.p: Ay, ay, before and behind, before and behind. [Exeunt Honeywood, Bailiff, and Follower.

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: What can all this mean, Garnet?

sp.speaker: GARNET.
sp.p: Mean, madam? why, what ſhould it mean, but what Mr. Lofty ſent you here to ſee? Theſe people he calls officers are officers ſure enough: ſheriff's officers; bailiffs, madam.

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: Ay, it is certainly ſo. Well, tho' his perplexities are far from giving me pleaſure, yet I own there's ſomething very ridiculous in them, and a juſt puniſhment for his diſſimulation.

sp.speaker: GARNET.
sp.p: And ſo they are. But I wonder, madam, that the lawyer you juſt employed to pay his debts, and ſet him free, has not done it by this time. He ought at leaſt to have been here before now. But lawyers are always more ready to get a man into troubles, than out of them.

sp.speaker: SIR WILLIAM.
sp.p: For miſs Richland to undertake ſetting him free, I own, was quite unexpected. It has totally unhinged my ſchemes to reclaim him. Yet, it gives me pleaſure to find, that, among a number of worthleſs friendſhips, he has made one acquiſition of real value; for there muſt be ſome ſofter paſſion on her ſide that prompts this generoſity. Ha! here before me: I'll endeavour to ſound her affections. Madam, as I am the perſon that have had ſome demands upon the gentleman of this houſe, I hope you'll excuſe me, if, before I enlarged him, I wanted to ſee yourſelf.

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: The precaution was very unneceſſary, ſir. I ſuppoſe your wants were only ſuch as my agent had power to ſatisfy.

sp.speaker: SIR WILLIAM.
sp.p: Partly, madam. But, I was alſo willing you ſhould be fully apprized of the character of the gentleman you intended to ſerve.

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: It muſt come, ſir, with a very ill grace from you. To cenſure it, after what you have done, would look like malice; and, to ſpeak favourably of a character you have oppreſſed, would be impeaching your own. And ſure, his tenderneſs, his humanity, his univerſal friendſhip, may atone for many faults.

sp.speaker: SIR WILLIAM.
sp.p: That friendſhip, madam, which is exerted in too wide a ſphere, becomes totally uſeleſs. Our bounty, like a drop of water, diſappears when diffuſed too widely. They, who pretend moſt to this univerſal benevolence, are either deceivers, or dupes. Men who deſire to cover their private ill-nature, by a pretended regard for all; or, men who, reaſoning themſelves into falſe feelings, are more earneſt in purſuit of ſplendid, than of uſeful virtues.

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: I am ſurpriſed, ſir, to hear one, who has probably been a gainer by the folly of others, ſo ſevere in his cenſure of it.

sp.speaker: SIR WILLIAM.
sp.p: Whatever I may have gained by folly, madam, you ſee I am willing to prevent your loſing by it.

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: Your cares for me, ſir, are unneceſſary. I always ſuſpect thoſe ſervices which are denied where they are wanted, and offered, perhaps, in hopes of a refuſal. No, ſir, my directions have been given, and I inſiſt upon their being complied with.

sp.speaker: SIR WILLIAM.
sp.p: Thou amiable woman! I can no longer contain the expreſſions of my gratitude: my pleaſure. You ſee before you one, who has been equally careful of his intereſt; one, who has for ſome time been a concealed ſpectator of his follies, and only puniſhed, in hopes to reclaim them—his uncle!

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: Sir William Honeywood! You amaze me. How ſhall I conceal my confuſion? I fear, ſir, you'll think I have been too forward in my ſervices. I confeſs I—

sp.speaker: SIR WILLIAM.
sp.p: Don't make any apologies, madam. I only find myſelf unable to repay the obligation. And yet, I have been trying my intereſt of late to ſerve you. Having learnt, madam, that you had ſome demands upon government, I have, tho' unaſked, been your ſolicitor there.

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: Sir, I'm infinitely obliged to your intentions. But my guardian has employed another gentleman who aſſures him of ſucceſs.

sp.speaker: SIR WILLIAM.
sp.p: Who, the important little man that viſits here? Truſt me, madam, he's quite contemptible among men in power, and utterly unable to ſerve you. Mr. Lofty's promiſes are much better known to people of faſhion, than his perſon, I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: How have we been deceived! As ſure as can be, here he comes.

sp.speaker: SIR WILLIAM.
sp.p: Does he! Remember I'm to continue unknown. My return to England has not as yet been made public. With what impudence he enters!

sp.speaker: LOFTY.
sp.p: Let the chariot—let my chariot drive off; I'll viſit to his grace's in a chair. Miſs Richland here before me! Punctual, as uſual, to the calls of humanity. I'm very ſorry, madam, things of this kind ſhould happen, eſpecially to a man I have ſhewn every where, and carried amongſt us as a particular acquaintance.

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: I find, ſir, you have the art of making the misfortunes of others your own.

sp.speaker: LOFTY.
sp.p: My dear madam, what can a private man like me do? One man can't do every thing; and then, I do ſo much in this way every day: let me ſee; ſomething conſiderable might be done for him by ſubſcription; it could not fail if I carried the liſt. I'll undertake to ſet down a brace of dukes, two dozen lords, and half the lower houſe, at my own peril.

sp.speaker: SIR WILLIAM.
sp.p: And, after all, it's more than probable, ſir, he might reject the offer of ſuch powerful patronage.

sp.speaker: LOFTY.
sp.p: Then, madam, what can we do? You know I never make promiſes. In truth, I once or twice tried to do ſomething with him in the way of buſineſs; but, as I often told his uncle, ſir William Honeywood, the man was utterly impracticable.

sp.speaker: SIR WILLIAM.
sp.p: His uncle! Then that gentleman, I ſuppoſe, is a particular friend of your.

sp.speaker: LOFTY.
sp.p: Meaning me, ſir?—Yes, madam, as I often ſaid, my dear ſir William, you are ſenſible I would do any thing, as far as my poor intereſt goes, to ſerve your family: but what can be done; there's no procuring firſt-rate places for ninth-rate abilities.

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: I have heard of ſir William Honeywood; he's abroad in employment: he confided in your judgment, I ſuppoſe.

sp.speaker: LOFTY.
sp.p: Why, yes, madam, I believe ſir William had ſome reaſon to confide in my judgment; one little reaſon, perhaps.

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: Pray, ſir, what was it?

sp.speaker: LOFTY.
sp.p: Why, madam—but let it go no further—it was I procured him his place.

sp.speaker: SIR WILLIAM.
sp.p: Did you, ſir?

sp.speaker: LOFTY.
sp.p: Either you or I, ſir.

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: This, Mr. Lofty, was very kind indeed.

sp.speaker: LOFTY.
sp.p: I did love him, to be ſure; he had ſome amuſing qualities; no man was fitter to be toaſt-maſter to a club, or had a better head.

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: A better head?

sp.speaker: LOFTY.
sp.p: Ay, at a bottle. To be ſure, he was as dull as a choice ſpirit: but hang it, he was grateful, very grateful; and gratitude hides a multitude of faults.

sp.speaker: SIR WILLIAM.
sp.p: He might have reaſon, perhaps. His place is pretty conſiderable, I'm told.

sp.speaker: LOFTY.
sp.p: A trifle, a mere trifle, among us men of buſineſs. The truth is, he wanted dignity to fill up a greater.

sp.speaker: SIR WILLIAM.
sp.p: Dignity of perſon, do you mean, ſir? I'm told he's much about my ſize and figure, ſir.

sp.speaker: LOFTY.
sp.p: Ay, tall enough for a marching regiment; but then he wanted a ſomething—a conſequence of form—a kind of a—I believe the lady perceives my meaning.

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: O, perfectly: you courtiers can do any thing, I ſee.

sp.speaker: LOFTY.
sp.p: My dear madam, all this is but a meer exchange: we do greater things for one another every day. Why, as thus, now: let me ſuppoſe you the firſt lord of the treaſury; you have an employment in you that I want; I have a place in me that you want; do me here, do you there: intereſt of both ſides, few words, flat, done and done, and its over.

sp.speaker: SIR WILLIAM.
sp.p: A thought ſtrikes me. (Aſide.) Now you mention ſir William Honeywood, madam; and as he ſeems, ſir, an acquaintance of yours; you'll be glad to hear he's arrived from Italy; I had it from a friend who knows him as well as he does me, and you may depend on my information.

sp.speaker: LOFTY.
sp.p: The devil he is! If I had known that, we ſhould not have been quite ſo well acquainted. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: SIR WILLIAM.
sp.p: He is certainly returned; and, as this gentleman is a friend of yours, he can be of ſignal ſervice to us, by introducing me to him; there are ſome papers relative to your affairs, that require diſpatch and his inſpection.

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: This gentleman, Mr. Lofty, is a perſon employed in my affairs: I know you'll ſerve us.

sp.speaker: LOFTY.
sp.p: My dear madam, I live but to ſerve you. Sir William ſhall even wait upon him, if you think proper to command it.

sp.speaker: SIR WILLIAM.
sp.p: That would be quite unneceſſary.

sp.speaker: LOFTY.
sp.p: Well, we muſt introduce you then. Call upon me—let me ſee—ay, in two days.

sp.speaker: SIR WILLIAM.
sp.p: Now, or the opportunity will be loſt for ever.

sp.speaker: LOFTY.
sp.p: Well, if it muſt be now, now let it be. But damn it, that's unfortunate; my lord Grig's curſed Penſacola buſineſs comes on this very hour, and I'm engaged to attend—another time—

sp.speaker: SIR WILLIAM.
sp.p: A ſhort letter to ſir William will do.

sp.speaker: LOFTY.
sp.p: You ſhall have it; yet, in my opinion, a letter is a very bad way of going to work; face to face, that's my way.

sp.speaker: SIR WILLIAM.
sp.p: The letter, ſir, will do quite as well.

sp.speaker: LOFTY.
sp.p: Zounds! ſir, do you pretend to direct me; direct me in the buſineſs of office? Do you know me, ſir? who am I?

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: Dear Mr. Lofty, this requeſt is not ſo much his as mine; if my commands—but you deſpiſe my power.

sp.speaker: LOFTY.
sp.p: Delicate creature! your commands could even controul a debate at midnight: to a power ſo conſtitutional, I am all obedience and tranquillity. He ſhall have a letter; where is my ſecretary? Dubardieu! And yet, I proteſt I don't like this way of doing buſineſs I think if I ſpoke firſt to ſir William—But you will have it ſo. [Exit with Miſs Richland.

sp.speaker: SIR WILLIAM,
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! This too is one of my nephew's hopeful aſſociates. O vanity, thou conſtant deceiver, how do all thy efforts to exalt, ſerve but to ſink us! Thy falſe colourings, like thoſe employed to heighten beauty, only ſeem to mend that bloom which they contribute to deſtroy. I'm not diſpleaſed at this interview: expoſing this fellow's impudence to the contempt it deſerves, may be of uſe to my deſign; at leaſt, if he can reflect, it will be of uſe to himſelf.

sp.speaker: SIR WILLIAM.
sp.p: How now, Jarvis, where's your maſter, my nephew?

sp.speaker: JARVIS.
sp.p: At his wit's end, I believe: he's ſcarce gotten out of one ſcrape, but he's running his head into another.

sp.speaker: SIR WILLIAM.
sp.p: How ſo?

sp.speaker: JARVIS.
sp.p: The houſe has but juſt been cleared of the bailiffs, and now he's again engaging tooth and nail in aſſiſting old Croaker's ſon to patch up a clandeſtine match with the young lady that paſſes in the houſe for his ſiſter.

sp.speaker: SIR WILLIAM.
sp.p: Ever buſy to ſerve others.

sp.speaker: JARVIS.
sp.p: Ay, any body but himſelf. The young couple, it ſeems, are juſt ſetting out for Scotland; and he ſupplies them with money for the journey.

sp.speaker: SIR WILLIAM.
sp.p: Money! how is he able to ſupply others, who has ſcarce any for himſelf?

sp.speaker: JARVIS.
sp.p: Why, there it is: he has no money, that's true; but then, as he never ſaid no to any requeſt in his life, he has given them a bill, drawn by a friend of his upon a merchant in the city, which I am to get changed; for you muſt know that I am to go with them to Scotland myſelf.

sp.speaker: SIR WILLIAM.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: JARVIS.
sp.p: It ſeems the young gentleman is obliged to take a different road from his miſtreſs, as he is to call upon an uncle of his that lives out of the way, in order to prepare a place for their reception, when they return; ſo they have borrowed me from my maſter, as the propereſt perſon to attend the young lady down.

sp.speaker: SIR WILLIAM.
sp.p: To the land of matrimony! A pleaſant journey, Jarvis.

sp.speaker: JARVIS.
sp.p: Ay, but I'm only to have all the fatigues on't.

sp.speaker: SIR WILLIAM.
sp.p: Well, it may be ſhorter, and leſs fatiguing, than you imagine. I know but too much of the young lady's family and connexions, whom I have ſeen abroad. I have alſo diſcovered that miſs Richland is not indifferent to my thoughtleſs nephew; and will endeavour, tho' I fear, in vain, to eſtabliſh that connexion. But, come, the letter I wait for muſt be almoſt finiſhed; I'll let you further into my intentions, in the next room. [Exeunt.

div.head: ACT THE FOURTH.

sp.speaker: LOFTY.
sp.p: WELL, ſure the devil's in me of late, for running my head into ſuch defiles, as nothing but a genius like my own could draw me from. I was formerly contented to huſband out my places and penſions with ſome degree of frugality; but, curſe it, of late I have given away the whole Court Regiſter in leſs time than they could print the title page: yet, hang it, why ſcruple a lie or two to come at a fine girl, when I every day tell a thouſand for nothing. Ha! Honeywood here before me. Could miſs Richland have ſet him at liberty?

Mr. Honeywood, I'm glad to ſee you abroad again. I find my concurrence was not neceſſary in your unfortunate affairs. I had put things in a train to do your buſineſs; but it is not for me to ſay what I intended doing.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: It was unfortunate indeed, ſir. But what adds to my uneaſineſs is, that while you ſeem to be acquainted with my misfortune, I, myſelf, continue ſtill a ſtranger to my benefactor.

sp.speaker: LOFTY.
sp.p: How! not know the friend that ſerved you?

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: Can't gueſs at the perſon.

sp.speaker: LOFTY.
sp.p: Inquire.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: I have; but all I can learn is, that he chuſes to remain concealed, and that all inquiry muſt be fruitleſs.

sp.speaker: LOFTY.
sp.p: Muſt be fruitleſs?

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: Abſolutely fruitleſs.

sp.speaker: LOFTY.
sp.p: Sure of that?

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: Very ſure.

sp.speaker: LOFTY.
sp.p: Then I'll be damn'd if you ſhall ever know it from me.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: How, ſir!

sp.speaker: LOFTY.
sp.p: I ſuppoſe now, Mr. Honeywood, you think my rent-roll very conſiderable, and that I have vaſt ſums of money to throw away; I know you do. The world to be ſure ſays ſuch things of me.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: The world, by what I learn, is no ſtranger to your generoſity. But where does this tend?

sp.speaker: LOFTY.
sp.p: To nothing; nothing in the world. The town, to be ſure, when it makes ſuch a thing as me the ſubject of converſation, has aſſerted, that I never yet patronized a man of merit.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: I have heard inſtances to the contrary, even from yourſelf.

sp.speaker: LOFTY.
sp.p: Yes, Honeywood, and there are inſtances to the contrary, that you ſhall never hear from myſelf.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: Ha! dear ſir, permit me to aſk you but one queſtion.

sp.speaker: LOFTY.
sp.p: Sir, aſk me no queſtions: I ſay, ſir, aſk me no queſtions; I'll be damn'd, if I anſwer them.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: I will aſk no further. My friend! my benefactor, it is, it muſt be here, that I am indebted for freedom, for honour. Yes, thou worthieſt of men, from the beginning I ſuſpected it, but was afraid to return thanks; which, if undeſerved, might ſeem reproaches.

sp.speaker: LOFTY.
sp.p: I proteſt I don't underſtand all this, Mr. Honeywood. You treat me very cavalierly. I do aſſure you, ſir.—Blood, ſir, can't a man be permitted to enjoy the luxury of his own feelings, without all this parade?

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: Nay, do not attempt to conceal an action that adds to your honour. Your looks, your air, your manner, all confeſs it.

sp.speaker: LOFTY.
sp.p:
Confeſs it, ſir! Torture itſelf, ſir, ſhall never bring me to confeſs it. Mr. Honeywood, I have
admitted you upon terms of friendſhip. Don't let us fall out; make me happy, and let this be buried in oblivion. You know I hate oſtentation; you know I do. Come, come, Honeywood, you know I always loved to be a friend, and not a patron. I beg this may make no kind of diſtance between us. Come, come, you and I muſt be more familiar—Indeed we muſt.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: Heavens! Can I ever repay ſuch friendſhip! Is there any way! Thou beſt of men, can I ever return the obligation?

sp.speaker: LOFTY.
sp.p: A bagatelle, a mere bagatelle. But I ſee your heart is labouring to be grateful. You ſhall be grateful. It would be cruel to diſappoint you.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: How! Teach me the manner. Is there any way?

sp.speaker: LOFTY.
sp.p: From this moment you're mine. Yes, my friend, you ſhall know it—I'm in love.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: And can I aſſiſt you?

sp.speaker: LOFTY.
sp.p: Nobody ſo well.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: In what manner? I'm all impatience.

sp.speaker: LOFTY.
sp.p: You ſhall make love for me.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: And to whom ſhall I ſpeak in your favour?

sp.speaker: LOFTY.
sp.p: To a lady with whom you have great intereſt, I aſſure you: miſs Richland.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: Miſs Richland!

sp.speaker: LOFTY.
sp.p: Yes, miſs Richland. She has ſtruck the blow up to the hilt in my boſom, by Jupiter.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: Heavens! was ever any thing more unfortunate! It is too much to be endured.

sp.speaker: LOFTY.
sp.p: Unfortunate indeed! And yet I can endure it, till you have opened the affair to her for me. Between ourſelves, I think ſhe likes me. I'm not apt to boaſt, but I think ſhe does.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: Indeed! But, do you know the perſon you apply to?

sp.speaker: LOFTY.
sp.p: Yes, I know you are her friend and mine: that's enough. To you, therefore, I commit the ſucceſs of my paſſion. I'll ſay no more, let friendſhip do the reſt. I have only to add, that if at any time my little intereſt can be of ſervice—but, hang it, I'll make no promiſes—you know my intereſt is yours at any time. No apologies, my friend, I'll not be anſwered, it ſhall be ſo. [Exit.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p:
Open, generous, unſuſpecting man! He little thinks that I love her too; and with ſuch an ardent paſſion!—But then it was ever but a vain and hopeleſs one; my torment, my perſecution! What ſhall I do! Love, friendſhip, a hopeleſs paſſion, a deſerving friend! Love, that has been my tormentor; a friend, that has, perhaps, diſtreſſed himſelf, to ſerve me. It ſhall be ſo. Yes, I will diſcard the fondling hope
from my boſom, and exert all my influence in his favour. And yet to ſee her in the poſſeſſion of another!—Inſupportable! But then to betray a generous, truſting friend!—Worſe, worſe! Yes, I'm reſolved. Let me but be the inſtrument of their happineſs, and then quit a country, where I muſt for ever deſpair of finding my own. [Exit.

div.stage: Enter OLIVIA, and GARNET, who carries a milliner's box.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA.
sp.p: Dear me, I wiſh this journey were over. No news of Jarvis yet? I believe the old peeviſh creature delays purely to vex me.

sp.speaker: GARNET.
sp.p: Why, to be ſure, madam, I did hear him ſay, a little ſnubbing, before marriage, would teach you to bear it the better afterwards.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA.
sp.p: To be gone a full hour, tho' he had only to get a bill changed in the city! How provoking!

sp.speaker: GARNET.
sp.p: I'll lay my life, Mr. Leontine, that had twice as much to do, is ſetting off by this time from his inn; and here you are left behind.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA.
sp.p: Well, let us be prepared for his coming, however. Are you ſure you have omitted nothing, Garnet?

sp.speaker: GARNET.
sp.p:
Not a ſtick, madam—all's here. Yet I wiſh you could take the white and ſilver to be married in. It's the worſt luck in the world, in any thing but white. I knew one Bett Stubbs, of our town, that was
married in red; and, as ſure as eggs is eggs, the bridegroom and ſhe had a miff before morning.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA.
sp.p: No matter. I'm all impatience till we are out of the houſe.

sp.speaker: GARNET.
sp.p: Bleſs me, madam, I had almoſt forgot the wedding-ring!—The ſweet little thing—I don't think it would go on my little finger. And what if I put in a gentleman's night-cap, in caſe of neceſſity, madam? But here's Jarvis.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA.
sp.p: O, Jarvis, are you come at laſt? We have been ready this half hour. Now let's be going. Let us fly!

sp.speaker: JARVIS.
sp.p: Aye, to Jericho; for we ſhall have no going to Scotland this bout, I fancy.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA.
sp.p: How! What's the matter?

sp.speaker: JARVIS.
sp.p: Money, money, is the matter, madam. We have got no money. What the plague do you ſend me of your fool's errand for? My maſter's bill upon the city is not worth a ruſh. Here it is; Mrs. Garnet may pin up her hair with it.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA.
sp.p: Undone! How could Honeywood ſerve us ſo! What ſhall we do? Can't we go without it?

sp.speaker: JARVIS.
sp.p:
Go to Scotland without money! To Scotland without money! Lord how ſome people underſtand
geography! We might as well ſet ſail for Patagonia upon a cork jacket.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA.
sp.p: Such a diſappointment! What a baſe inſincere man was your maſter, to ſerve us in this manner. Is this his good nature?

sp.speaker: JARVIS.
sp.p: Nay, don't talk ill of my maſter, madam. I won't bear to hear any body talk ill of him but myſelf.

sp.speaker: GARNET.
sp.p: Bleſs us! now I think on't, madam, you need not be under any uneaſineſs: I ſaw Mr. Leontine receive forty guineas from his father juſt before he ſet out, and he can't yet have left the inn. A ſhort letter will reach him there.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA.
sp.p: Well remember'd, Garnet; I'll write immediately. How's this! Bleſs me, my hand trembles ſo, I can't write a word. Do you write, Garnet; and, upon ſecond thought, it will be better from you.

sp.speaker: GARNET.
sp.p: Truly, madam, I write and indite but poorly. I never was kute at my larning. But I'll do what I can to pleaſe you. Let me ſee. All out of my own head, I ſuppoſe?

sp.speaker: OLIVIA.
sp.p: Whatever you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: GARNET.
sp.p: (Writing.) Muſter Croaker—Twenty guineas, madam?

sp.speaker: OLIVIA.
sp.p: Ay, twenty will do.

sp.speaker: GARNET.
sp.p:
At the bar of the Talbot till call'd for. Expedition—will be blown up—All of a flame—Quick
diſpatch—Cupid, the little god of love—I conclude it, madam, with Cupid; I love to ſee a love-letter end like poetry.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA.
sp.p: Well, well, what you pleaſe, any thing. But how ſhall we ſend it? I can truſt none of the ſervants of this family.

sp.speaker: GARNET.
sp.p: Odſo, madam, Mr. Honeywood's butler is in the next room: he's a dear, ſweet man; he'll do any thing for me.

sp.speaker: JARVIS.
sp.p: He! the dog, he'll certainly commit ſome blunder. He's drunk and ſober ten times a day.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA.
sp.p: No matter. Fly, Garnet: any body we can truſt will do. [Exit Garnet.] Well, Jarvis, now we can have nothing more to interrupt us. You may take up the things, and carry them on to the inn. Have you no hands, Jarvis?

sp.speaker: JARVIS.
sp.p: Soft and fair, young lady. You, that are going to be married, think things can never be done too faſt: but, we, that are old, and know what we are about, muſt elope methodically, madam.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA.
sp.p: Well, ſure, if my indiſcretions were to be done over again—

sp.speaker: JARVIS.
sp.p: My life for it, you would do them ten times over.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA.
sp.p: Why will you talk ſo? If you knew how unhappy they make me—

sp.speaker: JARVIS.
sp.p: Very unhappy, no doubt: I was once juſt as unhappy when I was going to be married myſelf. I'll tell you a ſtory about that—

sp.speaker: OLIVIA.
sp.p: A ſtory! when I'm all impatience to be away. Was there ever ſuch a dilatory creature!—

sp.speaker: JARVIS.
sp.p: Well, madam, if we muſt march, why we will march; that's all. Tho', odds bobs, we have ſtill forgot one thing we ſhould never travel without—a caſe of good razors, and a box of ſhaving-powder. But no matter, I believe we ſhall be pretty well ſhaved by the way. [Going.

sp.speaker: GARNET.
sp.p: Undone, undone, madam. Ah, Mr. Jarvis, you ſaid right enough. As ſure as death Mr. Honeywood's rogue of a drunken butler, dropp'd the letter before he went ten yards from the door. There's old Croaker has juſt pick'd it up, and is this moment reading it to himſelf in the hall.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA.
sp.p: Unfortunate! We ſhall be diſcover'd.

sp.speaker: GARNET.
sp.p: No, madam: don't be uneaſy, he can make neither head nor tail of it. To be ſure he looks as if he was broke looſe from Bedlam about it, but he can't find what it means for all that. O lud, he is coming this way all in the horrors!

sp.speaker: OLIVIA.
sp.p: Then let us leave the houſe this inſtant, for fear he ſhould aſk farther queſtions. In the mean time, Garnet, do you write and ſend off juſt ſuch another. [Exeunt.

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p:
Death and deſtruction! Are all the horrors of air, fire and water to be levelled only at me! Am I only to be ſingled out for gunpowder-plots, combuſtibles and conflagration! Here it is—An incendiary letter dropp'd at my door. 'To Muſter Croaker, theſe, with ſpeed.' Ay, ay, plain enough the direction: all in the genuine incendiary ſpelling, and as cramp as the devil. 'With ſpeed.' O, confound your ſpeed. But let me read it once more. (Reads.) 'Muſter Croaker as as ſone as yoew ſee this leve twenty gunnes at the bar of the Talboot tell caled for or yowe and yower experetion will be al blown up.' Ah, but too plain. Blood and gunpowder in every line of it. Blown up! murderous dog! All blown up! Heavens! what have I and my poor family done, to be all blown up! (Reads.) 'Our pockets are low, and money we muſt have.' Ay, there's the reaſon; they'll blow us up, becauſe they have got low pockets. (Reads.) 'It is but a ſhort time you have to conſider; for if this takes wind, the houſe will quickly be all of a flame.' Inhuman monſters! blow us up, and then burn us. The earthquake at Liſbon was but a bonfire to it. (Reads.) 'Make quick diſpatch, and ſo no more at preſent. But may Cupid, the little god of love, go with you wherever you go.' The little god of love! Cupid,
the little god of love go with me! Go you to the devil, you and your little Cupid together; I'm ſo frightened, I ſcarce know whether I ſit, ſtand, or go. Perhaps this moment I'm treading on lighted matches, blazing brimſtone and barrels of gunpowder. They are preparing to blow me up into the clouds. Murder! We ſhall be all burnt in our beds; we ſhall be all burnt in our beds.

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: Lord, ſir, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: Murder's the matter. We ſhall be all blown up in our beds before morning.

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: I hope not, ſir.

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: What ſignifies what you hope, madam, when I have a certificate of it here in my hand. Will nothing alarm my family! Sleeping and eating, ſleeping and eating is the only work from morning till night in my houſe. My inſenſible crew could ſleep, tho' rock'd by an earthquake; and fry beef ſteaks at a volcano.

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: But, ſir, you have alarmed them ſo often already, we have nothing but earthquakes, famines, plagues and mad dogs from year's end to year's end. You remember, ſir, it is not above a month ago, you aſſur'd us of a conſpiracy among the bakers, to poiſon us in our bread; and ſo kept the whole family a week upon potatoes.

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: And potatoes were too good for them. But why do I ſtand talking here with a girl, when I ſhould be facing the enemy without? Here, John, Nicodemus, ſearch the houſe. Look into the cellars, to ſee if there be any combuſtibles below; and above, in the apartments, that no matches be thrown in at the windows. Let all the fires be put out, and let the engine be drawn out in the yard, to play upon the houſe in caſe of neceſſity. [Exit.

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND, alone.
sp.p: What can he mean by all this? Yet, why ſhould I inquire, when he alarms us in this manner almoſt every day! But Honeywood has deſired an interview with me in private. What can he mean? or, rather, what means this palpitation at his approach! It is the firſt time he ever ſhewed any thing in his conduct that ſeemed particular. Sure he cannot mean to—but he's here.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: I preſumed to ſolicit this interview, madam, before I left town, to be permitted—

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: Indeed! Leaving town, ſir?—

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: Yes, madam; perhaps the kingdom. I have preſumed, I ſay, to deſire the favour of this interview,—in order to diſcloſe ſomething which our long friendſhip prompts. And yet my fears—

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: His fears! What are his fears to mine! (Aſide.) We have indeed been long acquainted, ſir; very long. If I remember, our firſt meeting was at the French ambaſſador's.—Do you recollect how you were pleaſed to rally me upon my complexion there?

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: Perfectly, madam: I preſumed to reprove you for painting: but your warmer bluſhes ſoon convinced the company, that the colouring was all from nature.

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: And yet you only meant it, in your good-natured way, to make me pay a compliment to myſelf. In the ſame manner you danced that night with the moſt aukward woman in company, becauſe you ſaw nobody elſe would take her out.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: Yes; and was rewarded the next night, by dancing with the fineſt woman in company, whom every body wiſhed to take out.

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: Well, ſir, if you thought ſo then, I fear your judgment has ſince corrected the errors of a firſt impreſſion. We generally ſhew to moſt advantage at firſt. Our ſex are like poor tradeſmen, that put all their beſt goods to be ſeen at the windows.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: The firſt impreſſion, madam, did indeed deceive me. I expected to find a woman with all the faults of conſcious flattered beauty. I expected to find her vain and inſolent. But every day has ſince taught me that it is poſſible to poſſeſs ſenſe without pride, and beauty without affectation.

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: This, ſir, is a ſtyle very unſual with Mr. Honeywood; and I ſhould be glad to know why he thus attempts to encreaſe that vanity, which his own leſſons have taught me to deſpiſe.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: I aſk pardon, madam. Yet, from our long friendſhip, I preſumed I might have ſome right to offer, without offence, what you may refuſe without offending.

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: Sir! I beg you'd reflect; tho', I fear, I ſhall ſcarce have any power to refuſe a requeſt of yours; yet you may be precipitate: conſider, ſir.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: I own my raſhneſs; but, as I plead the cauſe of friendſhip, of one who loves—Don't be alarmed, madam—who loves you with the moſt ardent paſſion; whoſe whole happineſs is placed in you—

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: I fear, ſir, I ſhall never find whom you mean, by this deſcription of him.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: Ah, madam, it but too plainly points him out; tho' he ſhould be too humble himſelf to urge his pretenſions, or you too modeſt to underſtand them.

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: Well; it would be affectation any longer to pretend ignorance; and I will own, ſir, I have long been prejudiced in his favour. It was but natural to wiſh to make his heart mine, as he ſeemed himſelf ignorant of its value.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p:
I ſee ſhe always loved him. (Aſide.) I find, madam, you're already ſenſible of his worth, his paſſion. How
happy is my friend, to be the favourite of one with ſuch ſenſe to diſtinguiſh merit, and ſuch beauty to reward it.

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: Your friend, ſir! What friend?

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: My beſt friend—my friend Mr. Lofty, madam.

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: He, ſir!

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: Yes, he, madam. He is, indeed, what your warmeſt wiſhes might have formed him. And to his other qualities, he adds that of the moſt paſſionate regard for you.

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: Amazement!—No more of this, I beg you, ſir.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: I ſee your confuſion, madam, and know how to interpret it. And, ſince I ſo plainly read the language of your heart, ſhall I make my friend happy, by communicating your ſentiments?

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: By no means.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: Excuſe me; I muſt; I know you deſire it.

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: Mr. Honeywood, let me tell you, that you wrong my ſentiments and yourſelf. When I firſt applied to your friendſhip, I expected advice and aſſiſtance; but, now, ſir, I ſee that it is vain to expect happineſs from him, who has been ſo bad an oeconomiſt of his own; and that I muſt diſclaim his friendſhip, who ceaſes to be a friend to himſelf. [Exit.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: How is this! ſhe has confeſſed ſhe loved him, and yet ſhe ſeemed to part in diſpleaſure. Can I have done any thing to reproach myſelf with? No; I believe not: yet, after all, theſe things ſhould not be done by a third perſon; I ſhould have ſpared her confuſion. My friendſhip carried me a little too far.

div.stage: Enter CROAKER, with the letter in his hand, and MRS. CROAKER.

sp.speaker: MRS. CROAKER.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! And ſo, my dear, it's your ſupreme wiſh that I ſhould be quite wretched upon this occaſion? ha, ha!

sp.speaker: CROAKER, mimicking.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! and ſo, my dear, it's your ſupreme pleaſure to give me no better conſolation?

sp.speaker: MRS. CROAKER.
sp.p: Poſitively, my dear; what is this incendiary ſtuff and trumpery to me? Our houſe may travel thro' the air like the houſe of Loretto, for aught I care, if I'm to be miſerable in it.

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: Would to heaven it were converted into an houſe of correction for your benefit. Have we not every thing to alarm us? Perhaps, this very moment the tragedy is beginning.

sp.speaker: MRS. CROAKER.
sp.p: Then let us reſerve our diſtreſs till the riſing of the curtain, or give them the money they want, and have done with them.

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: Give them my money!—And pray, what right have they to my money?

sp.speaker: MRS. CROAKER.
sp.p: And pray, what right then have you to my good humour?

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: And ſo your good humour adviſes me to part with my money? Why then, to tell your good humour a piece of my mind, I'd ſooner part with my wife. Here's Mr. Honeywood, ſee what he'll ſay to it. My dear Honeywood, look at this incendiary letter dropped at my door. It will freeze you with terror; and yet lovey here can read it—can read it, and laugh.

sp.speaker: MRS. CROAKER.
sp.p: Yes, and ſo will Mr. Honeywood.

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: If he does, I'll ſuffer to be hanged the next minute in the rogue's place, that's all.

sp.speaker: MRS. CROAKER.
sp.p: Speak, Mr. Honeywood; is there any thing more fooliſh than my huſband's fright upon this occaſion?

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: It would not become me to decide, madam; but doubtleſs, the greatneſs of his terrors, now, will but invite them to renew their villainy another time.

sp.speaker: MRS. CROAKER.
sp.p: I told you, he'd be of my opinion.

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: How, ſir! do you maintain that I ſhould lie down under ſuch an injury, and ſhew, neither by my tears, or complaints, that I have ſomething of the ſpirit of a man in me?

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: Pardon me, ſir. You ought to make the loudeſt complaints, if you deſire redreſs. The ſureſt way to have redreſs, is to be earneſt in the purſuit of it.

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: Ay, whoſe opinion is he of now?

sp.speaker: MRS. CROAKER.
sp.p: But don't you think that laughing off our fears is the beſt way?

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: What is the beſt, madam, few can ſay; but I'll maintain it to be a very wiſe way.

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: But we're talking of the beſt. Surely the beſt way is to face the enemy in the field, and not wait till he plunders us in our very bed-chamber.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: Why, ſir, as to the beſt, that—that's a very wiſe way too.

sp.speaker: MRS. CROAKER.
sp.p: But can any thing be more abſurd, than to double our diſtreſſes by our apprehenſions, and put it in the power of every low fellow, that can ſcrawl ten words of wretched ſpelling, to torment us?

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: Without doubt, nothing more abſurd.

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: How! would it not be more abſurd to deſpiſe the rattle till we are bit by the ſnake?

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: Without doubt, perfectly abſurd.

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: Then you are of my opinion?

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: Entirely.

sp.speaker: MRS. CROAKER.
sp.p: And you reject mine?

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: Heavens forbid, madam. No, ſure, no reaſoning can be more juſt than yours. We ought certainly to deſpiſe malice if we cannot oppoſe it, and not make the incendiary's pen as fatal to our repoſe as the highwayman's piſtol.

sp.speaker: MRS. CROAKER.
sp.p: O! then you think I'm quite right?

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: Perfectly right.

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: A plague of plagues, we can't be both right. I ought to be ſorry, or I ought to be glad. My hat muſt be on my head, or my hat muſt be off.

sp.speaker: MRS. CROAKER.
sp.p: Certainly, in two oppoſite opinions, if one be perfectly reaſonable, the other can't be perfectly right.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: And why may not both be right, madam: Mr. Croaker in earneſtly ſeeking redreſs, and you in waiting the event with good humour? Pray, let me ſee the letter again. I have it. This letter requires twenty guineas to be left at the bar of the Talbot inn. If it be indeed an incendiary letter, what if you and I, ſir, go there; and, when the writer comes to be paid his expected booty, ſeize him?

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: My dear friend, it's the very thing; the very thing. While I walk by the door, you ſhall plant yourſelf in ambuſh near the bar; burſt out upon the miſcreant like a maſqued battery; extort a confeſſion at once, and ſo hang him up by ſurpriſe.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: Yes; but I would not chuſe to exerciſe too much ſeverity. It is my maxim, ſir, that crimes generally puniſh themſelves.

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: Well, but we may upbraid him a little, I ſuppoſe? [Ironically.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: Ay, but not puniſh him too rigidly.

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: Well, well, leave that to my own benevolence.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: Well, I do: but remember that univerſal benevolence is the firſt law of nature. [Exeunt Honeywood and Mrs. Croaker.

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: Yes; and my univerſal benevolence will hang the dog, if he had as many necks as a hydra.

div.head: ACT THE FIFTH.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA.
sp.p: WELL, we have got ſafe to the inn, however. Now, if the poſt-chaiſe were ready—

sp.speaker: JARVIS.
sp.p: The horſes are juſt finiſhing their oats; and, as they are not going to be married, they chuſe to take their own time.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA.
sp.p: You are for ever giving wrong motives to my impatience.

sp.speaker: JARVIS.
sp.p: Be as impatient as you will, the horſes muſt take their own time; beſides, you don't conſider, we have got no anſwer from our fellow-traveller yet. If we hear nothing from Mr. Leontine, we have only one way left us.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA.
sp.p: What way?

sp.speaker: JARVIS.
sp.p: The way home again.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA.
sp.p: Not ſo. I have made a reſolution to go, and nothing ſhall induce me to break it.

sp.speaker: JARVIS.
sp.p: Ay; reſolutions are well kept, when they jump with inclination. However, I'll go haſten things without. And I'll call, too, at the bar, to ſee if any thing ſhould be left for us there. Don't be in ſuch a plaguy hurry, madam, and we ſhall go the faſter, I promiſe you. [Exit Jarvis.

sp.speaker: LANDLADY.
sp.p: What! Solomon, why don't you move? Pipes and tobacco for the Lamb there.—Will nobody anſwer? To the Dolphin; quick. The Angel has been outrageous this half hour. Did your ladyſhip call, madam?

sp.speaker: OLIVIA.
sp.p: No, madam.

sp.speaker: LANDLADY.
sp.p:
I find, as you're for Scotland, madam—But, that's no buſineſs of mine; married, or not married, I aſk
no queſtions. To be ſure, we had a ſweet little couple ſet off from this two days ago for the ſame place. The gentleman, for a taylor, was, to be ſure, as fine a ſpoken taylor, as ever blew froth from a full pot. And the young lady ſo baſhful, it was near half an hour before we could get her to finiſh a pint of raſberry between us.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA.
sp.p: But this gentleman and I are not going to be married, I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: LANDLADY.
sp.p: May be not. That's no buſineſs of mine; for certain, Scotch marriages ſeldom turn out. There was, of my own knowledge, miſs Macfag, that married her father's footman.—Alack-a-day, ſhe and her huſband ſoon parted, and now keep ſeparate cellars in Hedgelane.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA.
sp.p: A very pretty picture of what lies before me! [Aſide.

sp.speaker: LEONTINE.
sp.p: My dear Olivia, my anxiety, till you were out of danger, was too great to be reſiſted. I could not help coming to ſee you ſet out, tho' it expoſes us to a diſcovery.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA.
sp.p: May every thing you do prove as fortunate. Indeed, Leontine, we have been moſt cruelly diſappointed. Mr. Honeywood's bill upon the city has, it ſeems, been proteſted, and we have been utterly at a loſs how to proceed.

sp.speaker: LEONTINE.
sp.p: How! an offer of his own too. Sure, he could not mean to deceive us.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA.
sp.p: Depend upon his ſincerity; he only miſtook the deſire for the power of ſerving us. But let us think no more of it. I believe the poſt-chaiſe is ready by this.

sp.speaker: LANDLADY.
sp.p: Not quite yet: and, begging your ladyſhip's pardon, I don't think your ladyſhip quite ready for the poſt-chaiſe. The north road is a cold place, madam. I have a drop in the houſe of as pretty raſberry as ever was tipt over tongue. Juſt a thimble full to keep the wind off your ſtomach. To be ſure, the laſt couple we had here, they ſaid it was a perfect noſegay. Ecod, I ſent them both away as good natur'd—Up went the blinds, round went the wheels, and drive away poſtboy, was the word.

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: Well, while my friend Honeywood is upon the poſt of danger at the bar, it muſt be my buſineſs to have an eye about me here. I think I know an incendiary's look; for, wherever the devil makes a purchaſe, he never fails to ſet his mark. Ha! who have we here? My ſon and daughter! What can they be doing here!

sp.speaker: LANDLADY.
sp.p: I tell you, madam, it will do you good; I think I know by this time what's good for the north road. It's a raw night, madam.—Sir—

sp.speaker: LEONTINE.
sp.p: Not a drop more, good madam. I ſhould now take it as a greater favour, if you haſten the horſes, for I am afraid to be ſeen myſelf.

sp.speaker: LANDLADY.
sp.p: That ſhall be done. Wha, Solomon! are you all dead there? Wha, Solomon, I ſay. [Exit bawling.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA.
sp.p: Well; I dread, leſt an expedition begun in fear, ſhould end in repentance.—Every moment we ſtay increaſes our danger, and adds to my apprehenſions.

sp.speaker: LEONTINE.
sp.p: There's no danger, truſt me, my dear; there can be none: if Honeywood has acted with honour, and kept my father, as he promiſed, in employment till we are out of danger, nothing can interrupt our journey.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA.
sp.p: I have no doubt of Mr. Honeywood's ſincerity, and even his deſires to ſerve us. My fears are from your father's ſuſpicions. A mind ſo diſpoſed to be alarmed without a cauſe, will be but too ready when there's a reaſon.

sp.speaker: LEONTINE.
sp.p: Why, let him, when we are out of his power. But, believe me, Olivia, you have no great reaſon to dread his reſentment. His repining temper, as it does no manner of injury to himſelf, ſo will it never do harm to others. He only frets to keep himſelf employed, and ſcolds for his private amuſement.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA.
sp.p: I don't know that; but, I'm ſure, on ſome occaſions, it makes him look moſt ſhockingly.

sp.speaker: CROAKER, diſcovering himſelf.
sp.p: How does he look now?—How does he look now?

sp.speaker: OLIVIA.
sp.p: Ah!

sp.speaker: LEONTINE.
sp.p: Undone.

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p:
How do I look now? Sir, I am your very humble ſervant. Madam, I am yours. What, you are
going off, are you? Then, firſt, if you pleaſe, take a word or two from me with you before you go. Tell me firſt where you are going? and when you have told me that, perhaps, I ſhall know as little as I did before.

sp.speaker: LEONTINE.
sp.p: If that be ſo, our anſwer might but increaſe your diſpleaſure, without adding to your information.

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: I want no information from you, puppy: and you too, good madam, what anſwer have you got? Eh (A cry without, ſtop him.) I think I heard a noiſe. My friend Honeywood without—has he ſeized the incendiary? Ah, no, for now I hear no more on't.

sp.speaker: LEONTINE.
sp.p: Honeywood without! Then, ſir, it was Mr. Honeywood that directed you hither.

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: No, ſir, it was Mr. Honeywood conducted me hither.

sp.speaker: LEONTINE.
sp.p: Is it poſſible?

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: Poſſible! Why, he's in the houſe now, ſir: more anxious about me, than my own ſon, ſir.

sp.speaker: LEONTINE.
sp.p: Then, ſir, he's a villain.

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: How, ſirrah! a villain, becauſe he takes moſt care of your father? I'll not bear it. I tell you I'll not bear it. Honeywood is a friend to the family, and I'll have him treated as ſuch.

sp.speaker: LEONTINE.
sp.p: I ſhall ſtudy to repay his friendſhip as it deſerves.

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: Ah, rogue, if you knew how earneſtly he entered into my griefs, and pointed out the means to detect them, you would love him as I do. (A cry without, ſtop him) Fire and fury! they have ſeized the incendiary: they have the villain, the incendiary in view. Stop him, ſtop an incendiary, a murderer; ſtop him. [Exit.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA.
sp.p: Oh, my terrors! What can this new tumult mean?

sp.speaker: LEONTINE.
sp.p: Some new mark, I ſuppoſe, of Mr. Honeywood's ſincerity. But we ſhall have ſatisfaction: he ſhall give me inſtant ſatisfaction.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA.
sp.p: It muſt not be, my Leontine, if you value my eſteem or my happineſs. Whatever be our fate, let us not add guilt to our misfortunes—Conſider that our innocence will ſhortly be all we have left us. You muſt forgive him.

sp.speaker: LEONTINE.
sp.p: Forgive him! Has he not in every inſtance betrayed us? Forced me to borrow money from him, which appears a mere trick to delay us: promiſed to keep my father engaged till we were out of danger, and here brought him to the very ſcene of our eſcape?

sp.speaker: OLIVIA.
sp.p: Don't be precipitate. We may yet be miſtaken.

div.stage: Enter POSTBOY, dragging in JARVIS: HONEYWOOD entering ſoon after.

sp.speaker: POSTBOY.
sp.p:
Ay, maſter, we have him faſt enough. Here is the incendiary dog. I'm entitled to the reward; I'll take
my oath I ſaw him aſk for the money at the bar, and then run for it.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: Come, bring him along. Let us ſee him. Let him learn to bluſh for his crimes. (Diſcovering his miſtake.) Death! what's here! Jarvis, Leontine, Olivia! What can all this mean?

sp.speaker: JARVIS.
sp.p: Why, I'll tell you what it means: that I was an old fool, and that you are my maſter—that's all.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: Confuſion!

sp.speaker: LEONTINE.
sp.p: Yes, ſir, I find you have kept your word with me. After ſuch baſeneſs, I wonder how you can venture to ſee the man you have injured.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: My dear Leontine, by my life, my honour—

sp.speaker: LEONTINE.
sp.p: Peace, peace, for ſhame; and do not continue to aggravate baſeneſs by hypocriſy. I know you, ſir, I know you.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: Why, won't you hear me! By all that's juſt, I knew not—

sp.speaker: LEONTINE.
sp.p: Hear you, ſir! to what purpoſe? I now ſee through all your low arts; your ever complying with every opinion; your never refuſing any requeſt; your friendſhip as common as a proſtitute's favours, and as fallacious; all theſe, ſir, have long been contemptible to the world, and are now perfectly ſo to me.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: Ha! contemptible to the world! That reaches me. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: LEONTINE.
sp.p: All the ſeeming ſincerity of your profeſſions, I now find, were only allurements to betray; and all your ſeeming regret for their conſequences, only calculated to cover the cowardice of your heart. Draw, villain!

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: Where is the villain? Where is the incendiary? (Seizing the poſtboy.) Hold him faſt, the dog; he has the gallows in his face. Come, you dog, confeſs; confeſs all, and hang yourſelf.

sp.speaker: POSTBOY.
sp.p: Zounds! maſter, what do you throttle me for?

sp.speaker: CROAKER, beating him.
sp.p: Dog, do you reſiſt; do you reſiſt?

sp.speaker: POSTBOY.
sp.p: Zounds! maſter, I'm not he; there's the man that we thought was the rogue, and turns out to be one of the company.

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: Mr. Croaker, we have all been under a ſtrange miſtake here; I find there is nobody guilty; it was all an error; entirely an error of our own.

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: And I ſay, ſir, that you're in an error; for there's guilt and double guilt, a plot, a damned jeſuitical peſtilential plot, and I muſt have proof of it.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: Do but hear me.

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: What, you intend to bring 'em off, I ſuppoſe; I'll hear nothing.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: Madam, you ſeem at leaſt calm enough to hear reaſon.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA.
sp.p: Excuſe me.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: Good Jarvis, let me then explain it to you.

sp.speaker: JARVIS.
sp.p: What ſignifies explanations, when the thing is done?

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: Will nobody hear me? Was there ever ſuch a ſet, ſo blinded by paſſion and prejudice! (To the poſtboy.) My good friend, I believe you'll be ſurpriſed, when I aſſure you—

sp.speaker: POSTBOY.
sp.p: Sure me nothing—I'm ſure of nothing but a good beating.

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: Come, then, you, madam, if you ever hope for any favour or forgiveneſs, tell me ſincerely all you know of this affair.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA.
sp.p: Unhappily, ſir, I'm but too much the cauſe of your ſuſpicions: you ſee before you, ſir, one that with falſe pretences has ſtept into your family to betray it: not your daughter—

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: Not my daughter!

sp.speaker: OLIVIA.
sp.p: Not your daughter—but a mean deceiver—who—ſupport me, I cannot—

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: Help, ſhe's going, give her air.

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: Ay, ay, take the young woman to the air; I would not hurt a hair of her head, whoſe ever daughter ſhe may be—not ſo bad as that neither. [Exeunt all but Croaker.

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: Yes, yes, all's out; I now ſee the whole affair: my ſon is either married, or going to be ſo, to this lady, whom he impoſed upon me as his ſiſter. Ay, certainly ſo; and yet I don't find it afflicts me ſo much as one might think. There's the advantage of fretting away our misfortunes beforehand, we never feel them when they come.

div.stage: Enter MISS RICHLAND and SIR WILLIAM.

sp.speaker: SIR WILLIAM.
sp.p: But, how do you know, madam, that my nephew intends ſetting off from this place?

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: My maid aſſured me he was come to this inn, and my own knowledge of his intending to leave the kingdom, ſuggeſted the reſt. But what do I ſee, my guardian here before us! Who, my dear, ſir, could have have expected meeting you here? to what accident do we owe this pleaſure?

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: To a fool, I believe.

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: But, to what purpoſe did you come?

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: To play the fool.

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: But, with whom?

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: With greater fools than myſelf.

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: Explain.

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: Why, Mr. Honeywood brought me here, to do nothing, now I am here; and my ſon is going to be married to I don't know who, that is here: ſo now you are as wiſe as I am.

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: Married! to whom, ſir?

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: To Olivia; my daughter, as I took her to be; but who the devil ſhe is, or whoſe daughter ſhe is, I know no more than the man in the moon.

sp.speaker: SIR WILLIAM.
sp.p: Then, ſir, I can inform you; and, tho' a ſtranger, yet you ſhall find me a friend to your family: it will be enough, at preſent, to aſſure you, that, both in point of birth and fortune, the young lady is at leaſt your ſon's equal. Being left by her father, ſir James Woodville—

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: Sir James Woodville! What, of the weſt?

sp.speaker: SIR WILLIAM.
sp.p:
Being left by him, I ſay, to the care of a mercenary wretch, whoſe only aim was to ſecure her fortune to himſelf, ſhe was ſent into France, under pretence of education; and there every art was tried to fix her for life in a convent, contrary to her inclinations. Of this I was informed, upon my arrival at Paris; and,
as I had been once her father's friend, I did all in my power to fruſtrate her guardian's baſe intentions. I had even meditated to reſcue her from his authority, when your ſon ſtept in with more pleaſing violence, gave her liberty, and you a daughter.

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: But I intend to have a daughter of my own chuſing, ſir. A young lady, ſir, whoſe fortune, by my intereſt with thoſe that have intereſt, will be double what my ſon has a right to expect. Do you know Mr. Lofty, ſir?

sp.speaker: SIR WILLIAM.
sp.p: Yes, ſir; and know that you are deceived in him. But ſtep this way, and I'll convince you. [Croaker and Sir William ſeem to confer.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: Obſtinate man, ſtill to perſiſt in his outrage! Inſulted by him, deſpis'd by all, I now begin to grow contemptible, even to myſelf. How have I ſunk by too great an aſſiduity to pleaſe! How have I overtax'd all my abilities, leſt the approbation of a ſingle fool ſhould eſcape me! But all is now over; I have ſurvived my reputation, my fortune, my friendſhips, and nothing remains henceforward for me but ſolitude and repentance.

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: Is it true, Mr. Honeywood, that you are ſetting off, without taking leave of your friends? The report is, that you are quitting England. Can it be?

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: Yes, madam; and tho' I am ſo unhappy as to have fallen under your diſpleaſure, yet, thank Heaven, I leave you to happineſs; to one who loves you, and deſerves your love; to one who has power to procure you affluence, and generoſity to improve your enjoyment of it.

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: And are you ſure, ſir, that the gentleman you mean is what you deſcribe him?

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: I have the beſt aſſurances of it, his ſerving me. He does indeed deſerve the higheſt happineſs, and that is in your power to confer. As for me, weak and wavering as I have been, obliged by all, and incapable of ſerving any, what happineſs can I find but in ſolitude? What hope but in being forgotten?

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: A thouſand! to live among friends that eſteem you, whoſe happineſs it will be to be permitted to oblige you.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: No, madam; my reſolution is fix'd. Inferiority among ſtrangers is eaſy; but among thoſe that once were equals, inſupportable. Nay, to ſhew you how far my reſolution can go, I can now ſpeak with calmneſs of my former follies, my vanity, my diſſipation, my weakneſs. I will even confeſs, that, among the number of my other preſumptions, I had the inſolence to think of loving you. Yes, madam, while I was pleading the paſſion of another, my heart was tortur'd with its own. But it is over, it was unworthy our friendſhip, and let it be forgotten.

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: You amaze me!

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: But you'll forgive it, I know you will; ſince the confeſſion ſhould not have come from me even now, but to convince you of the ſincerity of my intention of—never mentioning it more. [Going.

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: Stay, ſir, one moment—Ha! he here—

sp.speaker: LOFTY.
sp.p: Is the coaſt clear? None but friends. I have followed you here with a trifling piece of intelligence: but it goes no farther, things are not yet ripe for a diſcovery. I have ſpirits working at a certain board; your affair at the treaſury will be done in leſs than—a thouſand years. Mum!

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: Sooner, ſir, I ſhould hope.

sp.speaker: LOFTY.
sp.p: Why, yes, I believe it may, if it falls into proper hands, that know where to puſh and where to parry; that know how the land lies—eh, Honeywood.

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: It is falien into yours.

sp.speaker: LOFTY.
sp.p: Well, to keep you no longer in ſuſpenſe, your thing is done. It is done, I ſay—that's all. I have juſt had aſſurances from lord Neverout, that the claim has been examined, and found admiſſible. Quictus is the word, madam.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: But how! his lordſhip has been at Newmarket theſe ten days.

sp.speaker: LOFTY.
sp.p: Indeed! Then ſir Gilbert Gooſe muſt have been moſt damnably miſtaken. I had it of him.

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p: He! why ſir Gilbert and his family have been in the country this month.

sp.speaker: LOFTY.
sp.p: This month! It muſt certainly be ſo—Sir Gilbert's letter did come to me from Newmarket, ſo that he muſt have met his lordſhip there; and ſo it came about. I have his letter about me; I'll read it to you. (Taking out a large bundle.) That's from Paoli of Corſica, that from the marquis of Squilachi.—Have you a mind to ſee a letter from count Poniatowſki, now king of Poland—Honeſt Pon— (Searching.) O, ſir, what are you here too? I'll tell you what, honeſt friend, if you have not abſolutely delivered my letter to ſir William Honeywood, you may return it. The thing will do without him.

sp.speaker: SIR WILLIAM.
sp.p: Sir, I have delivered it; and muſt inform you, it was received with the moſt mortifying contempt.

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: Contempt! Mr. Lofty, what can that mean?

sp.speaker: LOFTY.
sp.p: Let him go on, let him go on, I ſay. You'll find it come to ſomething preſently.

sp.speaker: SIR WILLIAM.
sp.p: Yes, ſir, I believe you'll be amazed, if, after waiting ſome time in the anti-chamber, after being ſurveyed with inſolent curioſity by the paſſing ſervants, I was at laſt aſſured, that ſir William Honeywood knew no ſuch perſon, and I muſt certainly have been impoſed upon.

sp.speaker: LOFTY.
sp.p: Good; let me die; very good. Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: Now, for my life, I can't find out half the goodneſs of it.

sp.speaker: LOFTY.
sp.p: You can't. Ha! ha!

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: No, for the ſoul of me; I think it was as confounded a bad anſwer, as ever was ſent from one private gentleman to another.

sp.speaker: LOFTY.
sp.p: And ſo you can't find out the force of the meſſage? Why, I was in the houſe at that very time. Ha! ha! It was I that ſent that very anſwer to my own letter. Ha! ha!

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: Indeed! How! why!

sp.speaker: LOFTY.
sp.p: In one word, things between ſir William and me muſt be behind the curtain. A party has many eyes. He ſides with lord Buzzard, I ſide with ſir Gilbert Gooſe. So that unriddles the myſtery.

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: And ſo it does, indeed; and all my ſuſpicions are over.

sp.speaker: LOFTY.
sp.p: Your ſuſpicions! What, then, you have been ſuſpecting, you have been ſuſpecting, have you? Mr. Croaker, you and I were friends; we are friends no longer. Never talk to me. It's over; I ſay, it's over.

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: As I hope for your favour, I did not mean to offend. It eſcaped me. Don't be diſcompoſed.

sp.speaker: LOFTY.
sp.p: Zounds! ſir, but I am diſcompoſed, and will be diſcompoſed. To be treated thus! Who am I! Was it for this, I have been dreaded both by ins and outs! Have I been libelled in the Gazetteer, and praiſed in the St. James's; have I been chaired at Wildman's, and a ſpeaker at Merchant-Taylor's Hall; have I had my hand to addreſſes, and my head in the print-ſhops; and talk to me of ſuſpects!

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: My dear ſir, be pacified. What can you have but aſking pardon?

sp.speaker: LOFTY.
sp.p: Sir, I will not be pacified—Suſpects! Who am I! To be uſed thus! Have I paid court to men in favour, to ſerve my friends; the lords of the treaſury, ſir William Honeywood, and the reſt of the gang, and talk to me of ſuſpects! Who am I, I ſay, who am I!

sp.speaker: SIR WILLIAM.
sp.p: Since, ſir, you're ſo preſſing for an anſwer, I'll tell you who you are. A gentleman, as well acquainted with politics, as with men in power; as well acquainted with perſons of faſhion, as with modeſty; with lords of the treaſury, as with truth; and with all, as you are with ſir William Honeywood. I am ſir William Honeywood. [Diſcovering his enſigns of the Bath.

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: Sir William Honeywood!

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: Aſtoniſhment! my uncle! [Aſide.

sp.speaker: LOFTY.
sp.p: So then, my confounded genius has been all this time only leading me up to the garret, in order to fling me out of the window.

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: What, Mr. Importance, and are theſe your works? Suſpect you! You, who have been dreaded by the ins and outs: you, who have had your hand to addreſſes, and your head ſtuck up in print-ſhops. If you were ſerved right, you ſhould have your head ſtuck up in the pillory.

sp.speaker: LOFTY.
sp.p: Ay, ſtick it where you will; for, by the Lord, it cuts but a very poor figure where it ſticks at preſent.

sp.speaker: SIR WILLIAM.
sp.p: Well, Mr. Croaker, I hope you now ſee how incapable this gentleman is of ſerving you, and how little miſs Richland has to expect from his influence.

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: Ay, ſir, too well I ſee it; and I can't but ſay I have had ſome boding of it theſe ten days. So, I'm reſolved, ſince my ſon has placed his affections on a lady of moderate fortune, to be ſatisfied with his choice, and not run the hazard of another Mr. Lofty, in helping him to a better.

sp.speaker: SIR WILLIAM.
sp.p: I approve your reſolution; and here they come, to receive a confirmation of your pardon and conſent.

div.stage: Enter MRS. CROAKER, JARVIS, LEONTINE, and OLIVIA.

sp.speaker: MRS. CROAKER.
sp.p: Where's my huſband! Come, come, lovey, you muſt forgive them. Jarvis here has been to tell me the whole affair; and, I ſay, you muſt forgive them. Our own was a ſtolen match, you know, my dear; and we never had any reaſon to repent of it.

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: I wiſh we could both ſay ſo. However, this gentleman, ſir William Honeywood, has been beforehand with you, in obtaining their pardon. So, if the two poor fools have a mind to marry, I think we can tack them together without croſſing the Tweed for it [Joining their hands.

sp.speaker: LEONTINE.
sp.p: How bleſt and unexpected! What, what can we ſay to ſuch goodneſs! But, our future obedience ſhall be the beſt reply. And, as for this gentleman, to whom we owe—

sp.speaker: SIR WILLIAM.
sp.p: Excuſe me, ſir, if I interrupt your thanks, as I have here an intereſt that calls me. (Turning to Honeywood.) Yes, ſir, you are ſurpriſed to ſee me; and I own that a deſire of correcting your follies led me hither. I ſaw, with indignation, the errors of a mind that only ſought applauſe from others; that eaſineſs of diſpoſition, which, though inclined to the right, had not courage to condemn the wrong. I ſaw, with regret, thoſe ſplendid errors, that ſtill took name from ſome neighbouring duty. Your charity, that was but injuſtice; your benevolence, that was but weakneſs; and your friendſhip, but credulity. I ſaw, with regret, great talents and extenſive learning, only employed to add ſprightlineſs to error, and encreaſe your perplexities. I ſaw your mind with a thouſand natural charms: but, the greatneſs of its beauty ſerved only to heighten my pity for its proſtitution.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p:
Ceaſe to upbraid me, ſir: I have for ſome time but too ſtrongly felt the juſtice of your reproaches. But there is one way ſtill left me. Yes, ſir, I have determined
this very hour, to quit for ever a place where I have made myſelf the voluntary ſlave of all; and to ſeek among ſtrangers that fortitude which may give ſtrength to the mind, and marſhal all its diſſipated virtues. Yet, ere I depart, permit me to ſolicit favour for this gentleman; who, notwithſtanding what has happened, has laid me under the moſt ſignal obligations. Mr. Lofty—

sp.speaker: LOFTY.
sp.p: Mr. Honeywood, I'm reſolved upon a reformation, as well as you. I now begin to find, that the man who firſt invented the art of ſpeaking truth was a much cunninger fellow than I thought him. And, to prove that I deſign to ſpeak truth for the future, I muſt now aſſure you, that you owe your late enlargement to another; as, upon my ſoul, I had no hand in the matter. So now if any of the company has a mind for preferment, he may take my place, I'm determined to reſign. [Exit.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: How have I been deceived!

sp.speaker: SIR WILLIAM.
sp.p: No, ſir, you have been obliged to a kinder, fairer friend for that favour. To miſs Richland. Would ſhe complete our joy, and make the man ſhe has honoured by her friendſhip happy in her love, I ſhould then forget all, and be as bleſt as the welfare of my deareſt kinſman can make me.

sp.speaker: MISS RICHLAND.
sp.p:
After what is paſt, it would be but affectation to pretend to indifference. Yes, I will own an attachment, which, I find, was more than friendſhip. And, if my intreaties cannot alter his reſolution to quit the
country, I will even try if my hand has not power to detain him. [Giving her hand.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: Heavens! how can I have deſerved all this? How expreſs my happineſs, my gratitude! A moment, like this, overpays an age of apprehenſion.

sp.speaker: CROAKER.
sp.p: Well, now I ſee content in every face; but heaven ſend we be all better this day three months.

sp.speaker: SIR WILLIAM.
sp.p: Henceforth, nephew, learn to reſpect yourſelf. He who ſeeks only for applauſe from without, has all his happineſs in another's keeping.

sp.speaker: HONEYWOOD.
sp.p: Yes, ſir, I now too plainly perceive my errors. My vanity, in attempting to pleaſe all, by fearing to offend any. My meanneſs in approving folly, leſt fools ſhould diſapprove. Henceforth, therefore, it ſhall be my ſtudy to reſerve my pity for real diſtreſs; my friendſhip for true merit; and my love for her, who firſt taught me what it is to be happy.

div.head: EPILOGUE.The author, in expectation of an Epilogue from a friend at Oxford, deferred writing one himſelf till the very laſt hour. What is here offered, owes all its ſucceſs to the graceful manner of the actreſs who ſpoke it.

lg.l: AS puffing quacks ſome caitiff wretch procure
To ſwear the pill, or drop, has wrought a cure;
Thus, on the ſtage, our play-wrights ſtill depend
For Epilogues and Prologues on ſome friend,
Who knows each art of coaxing up the town,
And make full many a bitter pill go down.
Conſcious of this, our bard has gone about,
And teaz'd each rhyming friend to help him out.
An Epilogue, things can't go on without it;
It cou'd not fail, wou'd you but ſet about it.
Young man, cries one, (a bard laid up in clover)
Alas, young man, my writing days are over;
Let boys play tricks, and kick the ſtraw, not I;
Your brother doctor there, perhaps, may try.
What I! dear ſir, the doctor interpoſes;
What, plant my thiſtle, ſir, among his roſes!
No, no, I've other conteſts to maintain;
To-night I head our troops at Warwick-lane.
Go, aſk your manager—Who, me! Your pardon;
Thoſe things are not our fort at Covent-garden.
Our author's friends, thus plac'd at happy diſtance,
Give him good words indeed, but no aſſiſtance.
As ſome unhappy wight, at ſome new play,
At the pit door ſtands elbowing away,
While oft, with many a ſmile, and many a ſhrug,
He eyes the centre, where his friends ſit ſnug;
His ſimpering friends, with pleaſure in their eyes,
Sinks as he ſinks, and as he riſes riſe:
He nods, they nod; he cringes, they grimace;
But not a ſoul will budge to give him place.
Since then, unhelp'd, our bard muſt now conform
To 'bide the pelting of this pittileſs ſtorm,
Blame where you muſt, be candid where you can,
And be each critic the Good-natur'd Man.

div.head: SHE STOOPS TO CONQUER: OR, THE MISTAKES OF A NIGHT. A COMEDY.
AS IT IS ACTED AT THE THEATRE-ROYAL, COVENT-GARDEN. FIRST PRINTED IN M,DCC,LXXII.
TO SAMUEL JOHNSON, L.L.D.
div.p: BY inſcribing this ſlight performance to you, I do not mean ſo much to compliment you as myſelf. It may do me ſome honour to inform the public, that I have lived many years in intimacy with you. It may ſerve the intereſts of mankind alſo to inform them that the greateſt wit may be found in a character, without impairing the moſt unaffected piety.

I have, particularly, reaſon to thank you for your partiality to this performance. The undertaking a comedy, not merely ſentimental, was very dangerous; and Mr. Colman, who ſaw this piece in its various ſtages, always thought it ſo. However I ventured to truſt it to the public; and, though it was neceſſarily delayed till late in the ſeaſon, I have every reaſon to be grateful. I am,

closer.signed: YOUR MOST SINCERE FRIEND AND ADMIRER, OLIVER GOLDSMITH.

div.head: PROLOGUE.
div.stage: Enter Mr. WOODWARD, dreſſed in black, and holding a handkerchief to his eyes.

lg.l: EXCUSE me, ſirs, I pray—I can't yet ſpeak—
I'm crying now—and have been all the week.
"'Tis not alone this mourning ſuit," good maſters;
"I've that within"—for which there are no plaſters!
I'ray, wou'd you know the reaſon why I'm crying?
The comic muſe, long ſick, is now a dying!
And if ſhe goes, my tears will never ſtop;
For as a play'r, I can't ſqueeze out one drop:
I am undone, that's all—ſhall loſe my bread—
I'd rather, but that's nothing—loſe my head.
When the ſweet maid is laid upon the bier,
Shuter and I ſhall be chief mourners here.
To her a mawkiſh drab of ſpurious breed,
Who deals in Sentimentals, will ſucceed!
Poor Ned and I are dead to all intents;
We can as ſoon ſpeak Greek as Sentiments!
Both nervous grown, to keep our ſpirits up,
We now and then take down a hearty cup.
What ſhall we do?—If Comedy forſake us!
They'll turn us out, and no one elſe will take us.
But, why can't I be moral?—Let me try—
My heart thus preſſing—fix'd my face and eye—
With a ſententious look, that nothing means,
(Faces are blocks, in ſentimental ſcenes)
Thus I begin—"All is not gold that glitters,
"Pleaſure ſeems ſweet, but proves a glaſs of bitters.
"When ign'rance enters, folly is at hand:
"Learning is better far than houſe and land.
"Let not your virtue trip, who trips may ſtumble,
"And virtue is not virtue, if ſhe tumble."
I give it up—morals won't do for me;
To make you laugh, I muſt play tragedy.
One hope remains—hearing the maid was ill,
A Doctor comes this night to ſhew his ſkill.
To chear her heart, and give your muſcles motion,
He, in Five Draughts prepar'd, preſents a potion:
A kind of magic charm—for be aſſur'd,
If you will ſwallow it, the maid is cur'd:
But deſp'rate the Doctor, and her caſe is,
If you reject the doſe, and make wry faces!
This truth he boaſts, will boaſt it while he lives,
No pois'nous drugs are mix'd in what he gives.
Should he ſucceed, you'll give him his degree;
If not, within he will receive no fee!
