sp.p: I proteſt, child, you uſe me extremely ill. If you keep me at this diſtance, how is it poſſible you and I can be ever acquainted?

sp.speaker: MISS HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: And who wants to be acquainted with you? I want no ſuch acquaintance, not I. I'm ſure you did not treat miſs Hardcaſtle that was here awhile ago in this obſtropalous manner. I'll warrant me, before her you look'd daſh'd, and kept bowing to the ground, and talk'd, for all the world, as if you was before a juſtice of peace.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: (Aſide) Egad! She has hit it, ſure enough. (To her) In awe of her, child? Ha! ha! ha! A mere, aukward, ſquinting thing, no, no. I find you don't know me. I laugh'd, and rallied her a little; but I was unwilling to be too ſevere. No, I could not be too ſevere, curſe me!

sp.speaker: MISS HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: O! then, ſir, you are a favourite, I find, among the ladies?

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Yes, my dear, a great favourite. And yet, hang me, I don't ſee what they find in me to follow. At the ladies club in town, I'm called their agreeable Rattle. Rattle, child, is not my real name, but one I'm known by. My name is Solomons. Mr. Solomons, my dear, at your ſervice. (Offering to ſalute her.)

sp.speaker: MISS HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Hold, ſir; you are introducing me to your club, not to yourſelf. And you're ſo great a favourite there, you ſay?

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Yes, my dear. There's Mrs. Mantrap, lady Betty Blackleg, the counteſs of Sligo, Mrs. Langhorns, old miſs Biddy Buckſkin, and your humble ſervant, keep up the ſpirit of the place.

sp.speaker: MISS HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Then it's a very merry place, I ſuppoſe?

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Yes, as merry as cards, ſupper, wine, and old women can make us.

sp.speaker: MISS HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: And their agreeable Rattle, ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: (Aſide) Egad! I don't quite like this chit. She looks knowing, methinks. You laugh, child!

sp.speaker: MISS HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: I can't but laugh to think what time they all have for minding their work or their family.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: (Aſide) All's well; ſhe don't laugh at me. (To her) Do you ever work, child?

sp.speaker: MISS HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Ay, ſure. There's not a ſcreen or a quilt in the whole houſe but what can bear witneſs to that.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Odſo! Then you muſt ſhew me your embroidery. I embroider and draw patterns myſelf a little. If you want a judge of your work you muſt apply to me. [Seizing her hand.

sp.speaker: MISS HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Ay, but the colours don't look well by candlelight. You ſhall ſee all in the morning. [Struggling.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: And why not now, my angel? Such beauty fires beyond the power of reſiſtance.—Pſhaw! the father here! My old luck: I never nick'd ſeven that I did not throw ames ace three times following. [Exit Marlow.

div.stage: Enter HARDCASTLE, who ſtands in ſurpriſe.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: So, madam. So I find this is your modeſt lover. This is your humble admirer that kept his eyes fixed on the ground, and only ador'd at humble diſtance. Kate, Kate, art thou not aſham'd to deceive your father ſo?

sp.speaker: MISS HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Never truſt me, dear papa, but he's ſtill the modeſt man I firſt took him for, you'll be convinced of it as well as I.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: By the hand of my body I believe his impudence is infectious! Didn't I ſee him ſeize your hand? Didn't I ſee him hawl you about like a milk-maid? and now you talk of his reſpect and his modeſty, forſooth!

sp.speaker: MISS HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: But if I ſhortly convince you of his modeſty, that he has only the faults that will paſs off with time, and the virtues that will improve with age, I hope you'll forgive him.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: The girl would actually make one run mad! I tell you I'll not be convinced. I am convinced. He has ſcarcely been three hours in the houſe, and he has already encroached on all my prerogatives. You may like his impudence, and call it modeſty. But my ſon-in-law, madam, muſt have very different qualifications.

sp.speaker: MISS HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Sir, I aſk but this night to convince you.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: You ſhall not have half the time, for I have thoughts of turning him out this very hour.

sp.speaker: MISS HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Give me that hour then, and I hope to ſatisfy you.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Well, an hour let it be then. But I'll have no trifling with your father. All fair and open, do you mind me.

sp.speaker: MISS HARDCASTLE.
sp.p:
I hope, ſir, you have ever found that I conſidered
your commands as my pride; for your kindneſs is ſuch, that my duty as yet has been inclination.

div.head: ACT THE FOURTH.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: YOU ſurpriſe me! Sir Charles Marlow expected here this night? Where have you had your information?

sp.speaker: MISS NEVILLE.
sp.p: You may depend upon it. I juſt ſaw his letter to Mr. Hardcaſtle, in which he tells him he intends ſetting out a few hours after his ſon.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: Then, my Conſtance, all muſt be completed before he arrives. He knows me; and ſhould he find me here, would diſcover my name, and perhaps my deſigns, to the reſt of the family.

sp.speaker: MISS NEVILLE.
sp.p: The jewels, I hope, are ſafe.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: Yes, yes. I have ſent them to Marlow, who keeps the keys of our baggage. In the mean time, I'll go to prepare matters for our elopement. I have had the Squire's promiſe of a ſreſh pair of horſes; and, if I ſhould not ſee him again, will write him further directions. [Exit.

sp.speaker: MISS NEVILLE.
sp.p: Well! ſucceſs attend you. In the mean time, I'll go amuſe my aunt with the old pretence of a violent paſſion for my couſin. [Exit.

div.stage: Enter MARLOW, followed by a ſervant.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: I wonder what Haſtings could mean by ſending me ſo valuable a thing as a caſket to keep for him, when he knows the only place I have is the ſeat of a poſt-coach at an inn-door. Have you depoſited the caſket with the landlady, as I ordered you? Have you put it into her own hands?

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: Yes, your honour.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: She ſaid ſhe'd keep it ſafe, did ſhe?

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: Yes, ſhe ſaid ſhe'd keep it ſafe enough; ſhe aſk'd me how I came by it? and ſhe ſaid ſhe had a great mind to make me give an account of myſelf. [Exit Servant.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! They're ſafe however. What an unaccountable ſet of beings have we got amongſt! This little bar-maid though runs in my head moſt ſtrangely, and drives out the abſurdities of all the reſt of the family. She's mine, ſhe muſt be mine, or I'm greatly miſtaken.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: Bleſs me! I quite forgot to tell her that I intended to prepare at the bottom of the garden. Marlow here, and in ſpirits too!

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Give me joy, George! Crown me, ſhadow me with laurels! Well, George, after all, we modeſt fellows don't want for ſucceſs among the women.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: Some women you mean. But what ſucceſs has your honour's modeſty been crowned with now, that it grows ſo inſolent upon us?

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Didn't you ſee the tempting, briſk, lovely, little thing that runs about the houſe with a bunch of keys to its girdle?

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: Well! and what then?

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: She's mine, you rogue you. Such fire, ſuch motion, ſuch eyes, ſuch lips—but, egad! ſhe would not let me kiſs them though.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: But are you ſo ſure, ſo very ſure of her?

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Why man, ſhe talked of ſhewing me her work above-ſtairs, and I am to improve the pattern.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: But how can you, Charles, go about to rob a woman of her honour?

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Pſhaw! pſhaw! We all know the honour of the bar-maid of an inn. I don't intend to rob her, take my word for it, there's nothing in this houſe, I ſnan't honeſtly pay for.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: I believe the girl has virtue.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: And if ſhe has, I ſhould be the laſt man in the world that would attempt to corrupt it.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: You have taken care, I hope, of the caſket I ſent you to lock up? It's in ſafety?

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Yes, yes. It's ſafe enough. I have taken care of it. But how could you think the ſeat of a poſt-coach at an inn door a place of ſafety? Ah! numbſkull! I have taken better precautions for you than you did for yourſelf.—I have—

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: What!

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: I have ſent it to the landlady to keep for you.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: To the landlady!

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: The landlady.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: You did?

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: I did. She's to be anſwerable for its forth-coming, you know.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: Yes, ſhe'll bring it forth, with a witneſs.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Wasn't I right? I believe you'll allow that I acted prudently upon this occaſion?

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: (Aſide) He muſt not ſee my uneaſineſs.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: You ſeem a little diſconcerted though, methinks. Sure nothing has happened?

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: No, nothing. Never was in better ſpirits in all my life. And ſo you left it with the landlady, who, no doubt, very readily undertook the charge?

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Rather too readily. For ſhe not only kept the caſket; but, thro' her great precaution, was going to keep the meſſenger too. Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: He! he! he! They're ſafe however.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: As a guinea in a miſer's purſe.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: (Aſide) So now all hopes of fortune are at an end, and we muſt ſet off without it. (To him) Well, Charles, I'll leave you to your meditations on the pretty bar-maid, and, he! he! he! may you be as ſucceſsful for yourſelf as you have been for me. [Exit.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Thank ye, George! I aſk no more. Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: I no longer know my own houſe. It's turned all topſey-turvey. His ſervants have got drunk already. I'll bear it no longer, and yet, from my reſpect for his father, I'll be calm. (To him) Mr. Marlow, your ſervant. I'm your very humble ſervant. (bowing low.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Sir, your humble ſervant. (Aſide) What's to be the wonder now?

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: I believe, ſir, you muſt be ſenſible, ſir, that no man alive ought to be more welcome than your father's ſon, ſir. I hope you think ſo?

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: I do from my ſoul, ſir. I don't want much intreaty. I generally make my father's ſon welcome wherever he goes.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: I believe you do, from my ſoul, ſir. But tho' I ſay nothing to your own conduct, that of your ſervants is inſufferable. Their manner of drinking is ſetting a very bad example in this houſe, I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p:
I proteſt, my very good ſir, that's no fault of mine. If they don't drink as they ought they are to blame. I ordered them not to ſpare the cellar. I did, I aſſure you. (To the ſide ſcene) Here, let one of my ſervants come up. (To him) My poſitive
directions were, that as I did not drink myſelf, they ſhould make up for my deſiciencies below.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Then they had your orders for what they do! I'm ſatisfied!

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: They had, I aſſure you. You ſhall hear from one of themſelves.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: You, Jeremy! Come forward, ſirrah! What were my orders? Were you not told to drink freely, and call for what you thought fit, for the good of the houſe?

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: (Aſide) I begin to loſe my patience.

sp.speaker: JEREMY.
sp.p: Pleaſe your honour, liberty and Fleet-ſtreet for ever! Tho' I'm but a ſervant, I'm as good as another man. I'll drink for no man before ſupper, ſir, dammy! Good liquor will ſit upon a good ſupper, but a good ſupper will not ſit upon—hiccup—upon my conſcience, ſir.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: You ſee, my old friend, the fellow is as drunk as he can poſſibly be. I don't know what you'd have more, unleſs you'd have the poor devil ſouſed in a beer-barrel.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p:
Zounds! he'll drive me diſtracted if I contain myſelf any longer. Mr. Marlow. Sir; I have
ſubmitted to your inſolence for more than four hours, and I ſee no likelihood of its coming to an end. I'm now reſolved to be maſter here, ſir, and I deſire that you and your drunken pack may leave my houſe directly.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Leave your houſe!—Sure you jeſt, my good friend? What, when I'm doing what I can to pleaſe you.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: I tell you, ſir, you don't pleaſe me; ſo I deſire you'll leave my houſe.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Sure you cannot be ſerious? At this time o'night, and ſuch a night. You only mean to banter me?

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: I tell you, ſir, I'm ſerious; and, now that my paſſions are rouzed, I ſay this houſe is mine, ſir; this houſe is mine, and I command you to leave it directly.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! A puddle in a ſtorm. I ſhan't ſtir a ſtep, I aſſure you. (In a ſerious tone) This, your houſe, fellow! It's my houſe. This is my houſe. Mine, while I chuſe to ſtay. What right have you to bid me leave this houſe, ſir? I never met with ſuch impudence, curſe me, never in my whole life before.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p:
Nor I, confound me if ever I did. To come to my houſe, to call for what he likes, to turn me out of my own chair, to inſult the family, to order his ſervants to get drunk, and then to tell me This houſe
is mine, ſir. By all that's impudent it makes me laugh. Ha! ha! ha! Pray, ſir, (bantering) as you take the houſe, what think you of taking the reſt of the furniture? There's a pair of ſilver candleſticks, and there's a fire-ſcreen, and here's a pair of brazen noſed bellows, perhaps you may take a fancy to them?

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Bring me your bill, ſir, bring me your bill, and let's make no more words about it.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: There are a ſet of prints too. What think you of the rake's progreſs for your own apartment?

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Bring me your bill, I ſay; and I'll leave you and your infernal houſe directly.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Then there's a mahogony table, that you may ſee your own face in.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: My bill, I ſay.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: I had forgot the great chair, for your own particular ſlumbers, after a hearty meal.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Zounds! bring me my bill, I ſay, and let's hear no more on't.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Young man, young man, from your father's letter to me, I was taught to expect a well-bred modeſt man, as a viſitor here, but now I find him no better than a coxcomb and a bully; but he will be down here preſently, and ſhall hear more of it. [Exit.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: How's this! Sure I have not miſtaken the houſe! Every thing looks like an inn. The ſervants cry, coming. The attendance is aukward; the bar-maid too to attend us. But ſhe's here, and will further inform me. Whither ſo faſt, child. A word with you.

sp.speaker: MISS HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Let it be ſhort then. I'm in a hurry. (Aſide) I believe he begins to find out his miſtake, but it's too ſoon quite to undeceive him.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Pray, child, anſwer me one queſtion. What are you, and what may your buſineſs in this houſe be?

sp.speaker: MISS HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: A relation of the family, ſir.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: What, a poor relation?

sp.speaker: MISS HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Yes, ſir. A poor relation appointed to keep the keys, and to ſee that the gueſts want nothing in my power to give them.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: That is, you act as the bar-maid of this inn.

sp.speaker: MISS HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Inn. O law—What brought that in your head? One of the beſt families in the county keep an inn! Ha, ha, ha, old Mr. Hardcaſtle's houſe an inn!

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Mr. Hardcaſtle's houſe! Is this houſe Mr. Hardcaſtle's houſe, child?

sp.speaker: MISS HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Ay, ſure. Whoſe elſe ſhould it be?

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: So then all's out, and I have been damnably impoſed on. O, confound my ſtupid head, I ſhall be laugh'd at over the whole town. I ſhall be ſtuck up in caricatura in all the print-ſhops. The Dulliſſimo Maccaroni. To miſtake this houſe of all others for an inn, and my father's old friend for an inn-keeper. What a ſwaggering puppy muſt he take me for. What a ſilly puppy do I find myſelf. There again, may I be hang'd, my dear, but I miſtook you for the bar-maid.

sp.speaker: MISS HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Dear me! dear me! I'm ſure there's nothing in my behaviour to put me upon a level with one of that ſtamp.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Nothing, my dear, nothing. But I was in for a liſt of blunders, and could not help making you a ſubſcriber. My ſtupidity ſaw every thing the wrong way. I miſtook your aſſiduity for aſſurance, and your ſimplicity for allurement. But its over—This houſe I no more ſhew my face in.

sp.speaker: MISS HARDCASTLE.
sp.p:
I hope, ſir, I have done nothing to diſoblige you. I'm ſure I ſhould be ſorry to affront any gentleman who has been ſo polite, and ſaid ſo many civil things to me. I'm ſure I ſhould be ſorry (pretending to cry) if he left the family upon my
account. I'm ſure I ſhould be ſorry, people ſaid any thing amiſs, ſince I have no fortune but my character.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: (Aſide) By heaven, ſhe weeps. This is the firſt mark of tenderneſs I ever had from a modeſt woman, and it touches me. (To her) Excuſe me, my lovely girl, you are the only part of the family I leave with reluctance. But to be plain with you, the difference of our birth, fortune and education, make an honourable connexion impoſſible; and I can never harbour a thought of ſeducing ſimplicity that truſted in my honour, of bringing ruin upon one, whoſe only fault was being too lovely.

sp.speaker: MISS HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: (Aſide) Generous man! I now begin to admire him. (To him) But I'm ſure my family is as good as miſs Hardcaſtle's, and though I'm poor, that's no great misfortune to a contented mind, and, until this moment, I never thought that it was bad to want fortune.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: And why now, my pretty ſimplicity?

sp.speaker: MISS HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Becauſe it puts me at a diſtance from one, that if I had a thouſand pound I would give it all to.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p:
(Aſide) This ſimplicity bewitches me, ſo that if I ſtay I'm undone. I muſt make one bold effort, and leave her. (To her) Your partiality in my favour, my dear, touches me moſt ſenſibly, and were I to live for myſelf alone, I could eaſily ſix my choice. But I owe too much to the opinion
of the world, too much to the authority of a father, ſo that—I can ſcarcely ſpeak it—it affects me. Farewel. [Exit.

sp.speaker: MISS HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: I never knew half his merit till now. He ſhall not go, if I have power or art to detain him. I'll ſtill preſerve the character in which I ſtoop'd to conquer, but will undeceive my papa, who, perhaps, may laugh him out of his reſolution. [Exit.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Ay, you may ſteal for yourſelves the next time. I have done my duty. She has got the jewels again, that's a ſure thing; but ſhe believes it was all a miſtake of the ſervants.

sp.speaker: MISS NEVILLE.
sp.p: But, my dear couſin, ſure you won't forſake us in this diſtreſs. If ſhe in the leaſt ſuſpects that I am going off, I ſhall certainly be locked up, or ſent to my aunt Pedigree's, which is ten times worſe.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: To be ſure, aunts of all kinds are damn'd bad things. But what can I do? I have got you a pair of horſes that will fly like Whiſtlejacket, and I'm ſure you can't ſay but I have courted you nicely before her face. Here ſhe comes, we muſt court a bit or two more, for fear ſhe ſhould ſuſpect us. [They retire, and ſeem to fondle.

sp.speaker: MRS. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Well, I was greatly fluttered, to be ſure. But my ſon tells me it was all a miſtake of the ſervants. I ſhan't be eaſy, however, till they are fairly married, and then let her keep her own fortune. But what do I ſee! fondling together, as I'm alive. I never ſaw Tony ſo ſprightly before. Ah! have I caught you, my pretty doves! What, billing, exchanging ſtolen glances, and broken murmurs. Ah!

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: As for murmurs, mother, we grumble a little now and then, to be ſure. But there's no love loſt between us.

sp.speaker: MRS. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: A mere ſprinkling, Tony, upon the flame, only to make it burn brighter.

sp.speaker: MISS NEVILLE.
sp.p: Couſin Tony promiſes to give us more of his company at home. Indeed, he ſhan't leave us any more. It won't leave us couſin Tony, will it?

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: O! it's a pretty creature. No, I'd ſooner leave my horſe in a pound, than leave you when you ſmile upon one ſo. Your laugh makes you ſo becoming.

sp.speaker: MISS NEVILLE.
sp.p: Agreeable couſin! Who can help admiring that natural humour, that pleaſant, broad, red, thoughtleſs, (patting his cheek) ah! it's a bold face.

sp.speaker: MRS. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Pretty innocence.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: I'm ſure I always lov'd couſin Con's hazle eyes, and her pretty long fingers, that ſhe twiſts this way and that, over the haſpicholls, like a parcel of bobbins.

sp.speaker: MRS. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Ah, he would charm the bird from the tree. I was never ſo happy before. My boy takes after his father, poor Mr. Lumpkin, exactly. The jewels, my dear Con, ſhall be yours incontinently. You ſhall have them. Isn't he a ſweet boy; my dear? You ſhall be married to-morrow, and we'll put off the reſt of his education, like Dr. Drowſy's ſermons, to a fitter opportunity.

sp.speaker: DIGGORY.
sp.p: Where's the 'ſquire? I have got a letter for your worſhip.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Give it to my mamma. She reads all my letters firſt.

sp.speaker: DIGGORY.
sp.p: I had orders to deliver it into your own hands.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Who does it come from?

sp.speaker: DIGGORY.
sp.p: Your worſhip mun aſk that o' the letter itſelf.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: I could wiſh to know, tho' (turning the letter, and gazing on it.)

sp.speaker: MISS NEVILLE.
sp.p: (Aſide) Undone, undone. A letter to him from Haſtings. I know the hand. If my aunt ſees it, we are ruined for ever. I'll keep her employ'd a little if I can. (To Mrs. Hardcaſtle) But I have not told you, madam, of my couſin's ſmart anſwer juſt now to Mr. Marlow. We ſo laugh'd—You muſt know, madam—This way a little, for he muſt not hear us. [They confer.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: (Still gazing) A damn'd cramp piece of penmanſhip, as ever I ſaw in my life. I can read your print hand very well. But here there are ſuch handles, and ſhanks, and daſhes, that one can ſcarce tell the head from the tail. "To Anthony Lumpkin, eſquire." It's very odd, I can read the outſide of my letters, where my own name is, well enough. But when I come to open it, it's all—buzz. That's hard, very hard; for the inſide of the letter is always the cream of the correſpondence.

sp.speaker: MRS. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! Very well, very well. And ſo my ſon was too hard for the philoſopher.

sp.speaker: MISS NEVILLE.
sp.p: Yes, madam; but you muſt hear the reſt, madam. A little more this way, or he may hear us. You'll hear how he puzzled him again.

sp.speaker: MRS. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: He ſeems ſtrangely puzzled now himſelf, methinks.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p:
(Still gazing) A damn'd up and down hand, as if 〈◊〉 was diſguiſed in liquor. (Reading) Dear ſir.
Ay, that's that. Then there's an M, and a T, and an S, but whether the next be an izzard or an R, confound me, I cannot tell.

sp.speaker: MRS. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: What's that, my dear. Can I give you any aſſiſtance?

sp.speaker: MISS NEVILLE.
sp.p: Pray, aunt, let me read it. No body reads a cramp hand better than I. (twitching the letter from her) Do you know who it is from?

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Can't tell, except from Dick Ginger the feeder.

sp.speaker: MISS NEVILLE.
sp.p: Ay, ſo it is. (pretending to read) Dear 'ſquire, hoping that you're in health, as I am at this preſent. The gentlemen of the Shake-bag club has cut the gentlemen of Gooſe-green quite out of feather. The odds—um—odd battle—um—long fighting—um—here, here, it's all about cocks, and fighting; it's of no conſequence, here, put it up, put it up. [Thruſting the crumpled letter upon him.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: But I tell you, miſs, it's of all the conſequence in the world. I would not loſe the reſt of it for a guinea. Here, mother, do you make it out. Of no conſequence! [Giving Mrs. Hardcaſtle the letter.

sp.speaker: MRS. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p:
How's this! (reads) Dear 'ſquire, I'm now waiting for miſs Neville, with a poſt-chaiſe and pair, at the bottom of the garden, but I find my horſes yet unable to perform the journey. I expect you'll aſſiſt us with a pair of freſh horſes, as you promiſed. Diſpatch is neceſſary, as the hag (ay the
hag) your mother, will otherwiſe ſuſpect us. Yours, Haſtings. Grant me patience. I ſhall run diſtracted. My rage choaks me.

sp.speaker: MISS NEVILLE.
sp.p: I hope, madam, you'll ſuſpend your reſentment for a few moments, and not impute to me any impertinence, or ſiniſter deſign, that belongs to another.

sp.speaker: MRS. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: (Curteſying very low.) Fine ſpoken, madam, you are moſt miraculouſly polite and engaging, and quite the very pink of curteſy and circumſpection, madam. (Changing her tone) And you, you great ill-faſhioned oaf, with ſcarce ſenſe enough to keep your mouth ſhut. Were you too join'd againſt me? But I'll defeat all your plots in a moment. As for you, madam, ſince you have got a pair of freſh horſes ready, it would be cruel to diſappoint them. So, if you pleaſe, inſtead of running away with your ſpark, prepare, this very moment, to run off with me. Your old aunt Pedigree will keep you ſecure, I'll warrant me. You too, ſir, may mount your horſe, and guard us upon the way. Here, Thomas, Roger, Diggory, I'll ſhew you, that I wiſh you better than you do yourſelves. [Exit.

sp.speaker: MISS NEVILLE.
sp.p: So now I'm completely ruined.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Ay, that's a ſure thing.

sp.speaker: MISS NEVILLE.
sp.p: What better could be expected from being connected with ſuch a ſtupid fool, and after all the nods and ſigns I made him.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: By the laws, miſs, it was your own cleverneſs, and not my ſtupidity, that did your buſineſs. You were ſo nice and ſo buſy with your Shake-bags and Gooſe-greens, that I thought you could never be making believe.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: So, ſir, I find by my ſervant, that you have ſhewn my letter, and betray'd us. Was this well done, young gentleman.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Here's another. Aſk miſs there who betray'd you. Ecod, it was her doing, not mine.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: So I have been finely uſed here among you. Rendered contemptible, driven into ill manners, deſpiſed, inſulted, laugh'd at.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Here's another. We ſhall have old Bedlam broke looſe preſently.

sp.speaker: MISS NEVILLE.
sp.p: And there, ſir, is the gentleman to whom we all owe every obligation.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: What can I ſay to him, a mere boy, an idiot, whoſe ignorance and age are a protection.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: A poor contemptible booby, that would but diſgrace correction.

sp.speaker: MISS NEVILLE.
sp.p: Yet with cunning and malice enough to make himſelf merry with all our embarraſſments.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: An inſenſible cub.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Replete with tricks and miſchief.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Baw! damme, but I'll fight you both one after the other,—with baſkets.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: As for him, he's below reſentment. But your conduct, Mr. Haſtings, requires an explanation. You knew of my miſtakes, yet would not undeceive me.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: Tortured as I am with my own diſappointments, is this a time for explanations. It is not friendly, Mr. Marlow.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: But, ſir—

sp.speaker: MISS NEVILLE.
sp.p: Mr. Marlow, we never kept on your miſtake, till it was too late to undeceive you. Be pacified.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: My miſtreſs deſires you'll get ready immediately, madam. The horſes are putting to. Your hat and things are in the next room. We are to go thirty miles before morning. [Exit ſervant.

sp.speaker: MISS NEVILLE.
sp.p: Well, well; I'll come preſently.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: (To Haſtings) Was it well done, ſir, to aſſiſt in rendering me ridiculous. To hang me out for the ſcorn of all my acquaintance. Depend upon it, ſir, I ſhall expect an explanation.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: Was it well done, ſir, if you're upon that ſubject, to deliver what I entruſted to yourſelf, to the care of another, ſir.

sp.speaker: MISS NEVILLE.
sp.p: Mr. Haſtings. Mr. Marlow. Why will you increaſe my diſtreſs by this groundleſs diſpute. I implore, I intreat you—

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: Your cloak, madam. My miſtreſs is impatient. Exit Servant.

sp.speaker: MISS NEVILLE.
sp.p: I come. Pray be pacified. If I leave you thus, I ſhall die with apprehenſion.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: Your fan, muff, and gloves, madam. The horſes are waiting.

sp.speaker: MISS NEVILLE.
sp.p: O Mr. Marlow! if you knew what a ſcene of conſtraint and ill-nature lies before me, I'm ſure it would convert your reſentment into pity.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p:
I'm ſo diſtracted with a variety of paſſions, that I don't know what I do. Forgive me, madam.
George, forgive me. You know my haſty temper, and ſhould not exaſperate it.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: The torture of my ſituation is my only excuſe.

sp.speaker: MISS NEVILLE.
sp.p: Well, my dear Haſtings, if you have that eſteem for me that I think, that I am ſure you have, your conſtancy for three years will but encreaſe the happineſs of our future connexion. If—

sp.speaker: MRS. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: (Within) Miſs Neville. Conſtance, why Conſtance, I ſay.

sp.speaker: MISS NEVILLE.
sp.p: I'm coming. Well, conſtancy. Remember, conſtancy is the word. [Exit.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: My heart! How can I ſupport this. To be ſo near happineſs, and ſuch happineſs.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: (To Tony) You ſee now, young gentleman, the effects of your folly. What might be amuſement to you, is here diſappointment, and even diſtreſs.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: (From a reverie) Ecod, I have hit it. It's here. Your hands. Yours and yours, my poor Sulky. My boots there, ho. Meet me two hours hence at the bottom of the garden; and if you don't find Tony Lumpkin a more good-natur'd fellow than you thought for, I'll give you leave to take my beſt horſe, and Bet Bouncer into the bargain. Come along. My boots, ho. [Exeunt.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: YOU ſaw the old lady and miſs Neville drive off, you ſay.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: Yes, your honour. They went off in a poſt coach, and the young 'ſquire went on horſeback. They're thirty miles off by this time.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: Then all my hopes are over.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: Yes, ſir. Old ſir Charles is arrived. He and the old gentleman of the houſe have been laughing at Mr. Marlow's miſtake this half hour. They are coming this way.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: Then I muſt not be ſeen. So now to my fruitleſs appointment at the bottom of the garden. This is about the time. [Exit.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! The peremptory tone in which he ſent forth his ſublime commands.

sp.speaker: SIR CHARLES.
sp.p: And the reſerve with which I ſuppoſe he treated all your advances.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: And yet he might have ſeen ſomething in me above a common inn-keeper, too.

sp.speaker: SIR CHARLES.
sp.p: Yes, Dick, but he miſtook you for an uncommon inn-keeper, ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Well, I'm in too good ſpirits to think of any thing but joy. Yes, my dear friend, this union of our families will make our perſonal friendſhips hereditary; and tho' my daughter's fortune is but ſmall—

sp.speaker: SIR CHARLES.
sp.p: Why, Dick, will you talk of fortune to me. My ſon is poſſeſſed of more than a competence already, and can want nothing but a good and virtuous girl to ſhare his happineſs and encreaſe it. If they like each other, as you ſay they do—

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: If, man! I tell you they do like each other. My daughter as good as told me ſo.

sp.speaker: SIR CHARLES.
sp.p: But girls are apt to flatter themſelves, you know.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: I ſaw him graſp her hand in the warmeſt manner myſelf; and here he comes to put you out of your ifs, I warrant him.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: I come, ſir, once more, to aſk pardon for my ſtrange conduct. I can ſcarce reflect on my inſolence without confuſion.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Tut, boy, a trifle. You take it too gravely. An hour or two's laughing with my daughter will ſet all to rights again. She'll never like you the worſe for it.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Sir, I ſhall be always proud of her approbation.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Approbation is but a cold word, Mr. Marlow; if I am not deceived, you have ſomething more than approbation thereabouts. You take me.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Really, ſir, I have not that happineſs.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Come, boy, I'm an old fellow, and know what's what, as well as you that are younger. I know what has paſt between you; but mum.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Sure, ſir, nothing has paſt between us but the moſt profound reſpect on my ſide, and the moſt diſtant reſerve on hers. You don't think, ſir, that my impudence has been paſt upon all the reſt of the family.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE
sp.p:
Impudence! No, I don't ſay that—not quite impudence—though girls like to be play'd with, and
and rumpled a little too ſometimes. But ſhe has told no tales, I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: I never gave her the ſlighteſt cauſe.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Well, well, I like modeſty in its place well enough. But this is over-acting, young gentleman. You may be open. Your father and I will like you the better for it.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: May I die, ſir, if I ever—

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: I tell you, ſhe don't diſlike you; and as I'm ſure you like her—

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Dear ſir—I proteſt, ſir—

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: I ſee no reaſon why you ſhould not be joined as faſt as the parſon can tie you.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: But hear me, ſir—

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Your father approves the match, I admire it, every moment's delay will be doing miſchief, ſo—

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: But why won't you hear me? By all that's juſt and true, I never gave miſs Hardcaſtle the ſlighteſt mark of my attachment, or even the moſt diſtant hint to ſuſpect me of affection. We had but one interview, and that was formal, modeſt and unintereſting.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: (Aſide) This fellow's formal modeſt impudence is beyond bearing.

sp.speaker: SIR CHARLES.
sp.p: And you never graſp'd her hand, or made any proteſtations!

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: As heaven is my witneſs, I came down in obedience to your commands. I ſaw the lady without emotion, and parted without reluctance. I hope you'll exact no further proofs of my duty, nor prevent me from leaving a houſe in which I ſuffer ſo many mortifications. [Exit.

sp.speaker: SIR CHARLES.
sp.p: I'm aſtoniſh'd at the air of ſincerity with which he parted.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: And I'm aſtoniſh'd at the deliberate intrepidity of his aſſurance.

sp.speaker: SIR CHARLES.
sp.p: I dare pledge my life and honour upon his truth.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Here comes my daughter, and I would ſtake my happineſs upon her veracity.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Kate, come hither, child. Anſwer us ſincerely, and without reſerve; has Mr. Marlow made you any profeſſions of love and affection?

sp.speaker: MISS HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: The queſtion is very abrupt, ſir! But ſince you require unreſerved ſincerity, I think he has.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: (To ſir Charles) You ſee.

sp.speaker: SIR CHARLES.
sp.p: And pray, madam, have you and my ſon had more than one interview?

sp.speaker: MISS HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Yes, ſir, ſeveral.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: (To ſir Charles) You ſee.

sp.speaker: SIR CHARLES.
sp.p: But did he profeſs any attachment?

sp.speaker: MISS HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: A laſting one.

sp.speaker: SIR CHARLES.
sp.p: Did he talk of love?

sp.speaker: MISS HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Much, ſir.

sp.speaker: SIR CHARLES.
sp.p: Amazing! And all this formally?

sp.speaker: MISS HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Formally.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Now, my friend, I hope you are ſatisfied.

sp.speaker: SIR CHARLES.
sp.p: And how did he behave, madam?

sp.speaker: MISS HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: As moſt profeſt admirers do. Said ſome civil things of my face, talked much of his want of merit, and the greatneſs of mine; mentioned his heart, gave a ſhort tragedy ſpeech, and ended with pretended rapture.

sp.speaker: SIR CHARLES.
sp.p: Now I'm perfectly convinced, indeed. I know his converſation among women to be modeſt and ſubmiſſive. This forward canting ranting manner by no means deſcribes him, and, I am confident, he never ſate for the picture.

sp.speaker: MISS HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Then what, ſir, if I ſhould convince you to your face of my ſincerity? If you and my papa, in about half an hour, will place yourſelves behind that ſcreen, you ſhall hear him declare his paſſion to me in perſon.

sp.speaker: SIR CHARLES.
sp.p: Agreed. And if I find him what you deſcribe, all my happineſs in him muſt have an end. [Exit.

sp.speaker: MISS HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: And if you don't find him what I deſcribe—I fear my happineſs muſt never have a beginning. [Exeunt.

div.stage: SCENE changes to the back of the garden.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: What an idiot am I, to wait here for a fellow, who probably takes a delight in mortifying me. He never intended to be punctual, and I'll wait no longer. What do I ſee. It is he, and perhaps with news of my Conſtance.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: My honeſt 'ſquire! I now find you a man of your word. This looks like friendſhip.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Ay, I'm your friend, and the beſt friend you have in the world, if you knew but all. This riding by night, by the bye, is curſedly tireſome. It has ſhook me worſe than the baſket of a ſtagecoach.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: But how? Where did you leave your fellow travellers? Are they in ſafety? Are they houſed?

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Five and twenty miles in two hours and a half is no ſuch bad driving. The poor beaſts have ſmoaked for it: rabbet me, but I'd rather ride forty miles after a fox, than ten with ſuch varment.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: Well, but where have you left the ladies? I die with impatience.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Left them! Why where ſhould I leave them, but where I found them?

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: This is a riddle.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Riddle me this then. What's that goes round the houſe, and round the houſe, and never touches the houſe?

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: I'm ſtill aſtray.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Why that's it, mon. I have led them aſtray. By jingo, there's not a pond or ſlough within five miles of the place but they can tell the taſte of.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, I underſtand; you took them in a round, while they ſuppoſed themſelves going forward. And ſo you have at laſt brought them home again.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: You ſhall hear. I firſt took them down Feather-bed-lane, where we ſtuck faſt in the mud. I then rattled them crack over the ſtones of Up-anddown Hill—I then introduc'd them to the gibbet on Heavy-tree Heath, and from that, with a circumbendibus, I fairly lodged them in the horſe-pond at the bottom of the garden.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: But no accident, I hope.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: No, no. Only mother is confoundedly frightened. She thinks herſelf forty miles off. She's ſick of the journey, and the cattle can ſcarce crawl. So if your own horſes be ready, you may whip off with couſin, and I'll be bound that no ſoul here can budge a foot to follow you.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: My dear friend, how can I be grateful?

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p:
Ay, now its dear friend, noble 'ſquire. Juſt now, it was all idiot, cub, and run me through
the guts. Damn your way of fighting, I ſay. After we take a knock in this part of the country, we kiſs and be friends. But if you had run me through the guts, then I ſhould be dead, and you might go kiſs the hangman.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: The rebuke is juſt. But I muſt haſten to relieve miſs Neville; if you keep the old lady employed, I promiſe to take care of the young one. [Exit Haſtings.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Never fear me. Here ſhe comes. Vaniſh. She's got from the pond, and draggled up to the waiſt like a mermaid.

sp.speaker: MRS. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Oh, Tony, I'm killed. Shook. Battered to death. I ſhall never ſurvive it. That laſt jolt that laid us againſt the quickſet hedge has done my buſineſs.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Alack, mamma, it was all your own fault. You would be for running away by night, without knowing one inch of the way.

sp.speaker: MRS. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: I wiſh we were at home again. I never met ſo many accidents in ſo ſhort a journey. Drench'd in the mud, overturn'd in a ditch, ſtuck faſt in a ſlough, jolted to a jelly, and at laſt to loſe our way. Whereabouts do you think we are, Tony?

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: By my gueſs we ſhould come upon Crackſkull common, about forty miles from home.

sp.speaker: MRS. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: O lud! O lud! The moſt notorious ſpot in all the country. We only want a robbery to make a complete night on't.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Don't be afraid, mamma, don't be afraid. Two of the five that kept here are hanged, and the other three may not find us. Don't be afraid. Is that a man that's galloping behind us? No; it's only a tree. Don't be afraid.

sp.speaker: MRS. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: The fright will certainly kill me.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Do you ſee any thing like a black hat moving behind the thicket?

sp.speaker: MRS. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: O death!

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: No, it's only a cow. Don't be afraid, mamma; don't be afraid.

sp.speaker: MRS. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: As I'm alive, Tony, I ſee a man coming towards us. Ah! I'm ſure on't. If he perceives us we are undone.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: (Aſide) Father-in-law, by all that's unlucky, come to take one of his night walks. (To her) Ah, it's a highwayman, with piſtils as long as my arm. A damn'd ill-looking fellow.

sp.speaker: MRS. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Good heaven defend us! He approaches.

sp.speaker: TONY
sp.p: Do you hide yourſelf in that thicket, and leave me to manage him. If there be any danger I'll cough and cry hem. When I cough be ſure to keep cloſe. [Mrs. Hardcaſtle hides behind a tree in the back ſcene.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: I'm miſtaken, or I heard voices of people in want of help. Oh, Tony, is that you. I did not expect you ſo ſoon back. Are your mother and her charge in ſafety?

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Very ſafe, ſir, at my aunt Pedigree's. Hem.

sp.speaker: MRS. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: (From behind) Ah death! I find there's danger.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Forty miles in three hours; ſure, that's too much, my youngſter.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Stout horſes and willing minds make ſhort journies, as they ſay. Hem.

sp.speaker: MRS. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: (From behind) Sure he'll do the dear boy no harm.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: But I heard a voice here; I ſhould be glad to know from whence it came?

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p:
It was I, ſir, talking to myſelf, ſir. I was ſaying that forty miles in four hours was very good going.
Hem. As to be ſure it was. Hem. I have got a ſort of cold by being out in the air. We'll go in, if you pleaſe. Hem.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: But if you talk'd to yourſelf, you did not anſwer yourſelf. I am certain I heard two voices, and am reſolved (raiſing his voice) to find the other out.

sp.speaker: MRS. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: (From behind) Oh! he's coming to find me out. Oh!

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: What need you go, ſir, if I tell you. Hem. I'll lay down my life for the truth—hem—I'll tell you all, ſir. [detaining him.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: I tell you, I will not be detained. I inſiſt on ſeeing. It's in vain to expect I'll believe you.

sp.speaker: MRS. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: (Running forward from behind) O lud, he'll murder my poor boy, my darling. Here, good gentleman, whet your rage upon me. Take my money, my life, but ſpare that young gentleman, ſpare my child, if you have any mercy.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: My wife! as I'm a chriſtian. From whence can ſhe come, or what does ſhe mean!

sp.speaker: MRS. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: (Kneeling) Take compaſſion on us, good Mr. Highwayman. Take our money, our watches, all we have, but ſpare our lives. We will never bring you to juſtice, indeed we won't, good Mr. Highwayman.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: I believe the woman's out of her ſenſes. What, Dorothy, don't you know me?

sp.speaker: MRS. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Mr. Hardcaſtle, as I'm alive! My fears blinded me. But who, my dear, could have expected to meet you here, in this frightful place, ſo far from home. What has brought you to follow us?

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Sure, Dorothy, you have not loſt your wits. So far from home, when you are within forty yards of your own door. (To him) This is one of your old tricks, you graceleſs rogue you. (To her) Don't you know the gate, and the mulberry-tree; and don't you remember the horſepond, my dear?

sp.speaker: MRS. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Yes, I ſhall remember the horſepond as long as I live; I have caught my death in it. (To Tony) And is it to you, you graceleſs varlet, I owe all this. I'll teach you to abuſe your mother, I will.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Ecod, mother, all the pariſh ſays you have ſpoil'd me, and ſo you may take the fruits on't.

sp.speaker: MRS. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: I'll ſpoil you, I will. [Follows him off the ſtage. Exit.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: There's morality, however, in his reply. [Exit.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: My dear Conſtance, why will you deliberate thus? If we delay a moment, all is loſt for ever. Pluck up a little reſolution, and we ſhall ſoon be out of the reach of her malignity.

sp.speaker: MISS NEVILLE.
sp.p: I find it impoſſible. My ſpirits are ſo ſunk with the agitations I have ſuffered, that I am unable to face any new danger. Two or three years patience will at laſt crown us with happineſs.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: Such a tedious delay is worſe than inconſtancy. Let us fly, my charmer. Let us date our happineſs from this very moment. Periſh fortune. Love and content will encreaſe what we poſſeſs beyond a monarch's revenue. Let me prevail.

sp.speaker: MISS NEVILLE.
sp.p: No, Mr. Haſtings; no. Prudence once more comes to my relief, and I will obey its dictates. In the moment of paſſion, fortune may be deſpiſed, but it ever produces a laſting repentance. I'm reſolved to apply to Mr. Hardcaſtle's compaſſion and juſtice for redreſs.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: But tho' he had the will, he has not the power to relieve you.

sp.speaker: MISS NEVILLE.
sp.p: But he has influence, and upon that I am reſolved to rely.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: I have no hopes. But ſince you perſiſt, I muſt reluctantly obey you. [Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter SIR CHARLES and MISS HARDCASTLE.

sp.speaker: SIR CHARLES.
sp.p: What a ſituation am I in. If what you ſay appears, I ſhall then find a guilty ſon. If what he ſays be true, I ſhall then loſe one, that, of all others, I moſt wiſh'd for a daughter.

sp.speaker: MISS HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: I am proud of your approbation, and to ſhew I merit it, if you place yourſelves as I directed, you ſhall hear his explicit declaration. But he comes.

sp.speaker: SIR CHARLES.
sp.p: I'll to your father, and keep him to the appointment. [Exit ſir Charles.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Tho' prepar'd for ſetting out, I come once more to take leave, nor did I, till this moment, know the pain I feel in the ſeparation.

sp.speaker: MISS HARDCASTLE.
sp.p:
(In her own natural manner) I believe theſe ſufferings cannot be very great, ſir, which you can ſo eaſily remove. A day or two longer, perhaps, might
leſſen your uneaſineſs, by ſhewing the little value of what you now think proper to regret.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: (Aſide) This girl every moment improves upon me. (To her) It muſt not be, madam. I have already trifled too long with my heart. My very pride begins to ſubmit to my paſſion. The diſparity of education and fortune, the anger of a parent, and the contempt of my equals, begin to loſe their weight; and nothing can reſtore me to myſelf, but this painful effort of reſolution.

sp.speaker: MISS HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Then go, ſir. I'll urge nothing more to detain you. Tho' my family be as good as hers you came down to viſit, and my education, I hope, not inferior, what are theſe advantages without equal affluence? I muſt remain contented with the ſlight approbation of imputed merit; I muſt have only the mockery of your addreſſes, while all your ſerious aims are fix'd on fortune.

div.stage: Enter HARDCASTLE and SIR CHARLES from behind.

sp.speaker: SIR CHARLES.
sp.p: Here, behind this ſcreen.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Ay, ay, make no noiſe. I'll engage my Kate covers him with confuſion at laſt.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p:
By heavens, madam, fortune was ever my ſmalleſt conſideration. Your beauty at firſt caught my eye; for who could ſee that without emotion.
But every moment that I converſe with you, ſteals in ſome new grace, heightens the picture, and gives it ſtronger expreſſion. What at firſt ſeem'd ruſtic plainneſs, now appears refin'd ſimplicity. What ſeem'd forward aſſurance, now ſtrikes me as the reſult of courageous innocence, and conſcious virtue.

sp.speaker: SIR CHARLES.
sp.p: What can it mean! He amazes me!

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: I told you how it would be. Huſh!

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: I am now determined to ſtay, madam, and I have too good an opinion of my father's diſcernment, when he ſees you, to doubt his approbation.

sp.speaker: MISS HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: No, Mr. Marlow, I will not, cannot detain you. Do you think I could ſuffer a connexion, in which there is the ſmalleſt room for repentance? Do you think I would take the mean advantage of a tranſient paſſion, to load you with confuſion? Do you think I could ever reliſh that happineſs, which was acquired by leſſening yours?

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: By all that's good, I can have no happineſs but what's in your power to grant me. Nor ſhall I ever feel repentance, but in not having ſeen your merits before. I will ſtay, even contrary to your wiſhes; and tho' you ſhould perſiſt to ſhun me, I will make my reſpectful aſſiduities atone for the levity of my paſt conduct.

sp.speaker: MISS HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Sir, I muſt entreat you'll deſiſt. As our acquaintance began, ſo let it end, in indifference. I might have given an hour or two to levity; but ſeriouſly, Mr. Marlow, do you think I could ever ſubmit to a connexion, where I muſt appear mercenary, and you imprudent? Do you think I could ever catch at the confident addreſſes of a ſecure admirer?

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: (Kneeling) Does this look like ſecurity. Does this look like confidence. No, madam, every moment that ſhews me your merit, only ſerves to encreaſe my diffidence and confuſion. Here let me continue—

sp.speaker: SIR CHARLES.
sp.p: I can hold it no longer. Charles, Charles, how haſt thou deceived me! Is this your indifference, your unintereſting converſation!

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Your cold contempt; your formal interview. What have you to ſay now?

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: That I'm all amazement! What can it mean!

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: It means that you can ſay and unſay things at pleaſure. That you can addreſs a lady in private, and deny it in public; that you have one ſtory for us, and another for my daughter.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Daughter!—this lady your daughter!

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Yes, ſir, my only daughter. My Kate, whoſe elſe ſhould ſhe be?

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Oh, the devil!

sp.speaker: MISS HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Yes, ſir, that very identical tall ſquinting lady you were pleaſed to take me for, (curteſying) ſhe that you addreſſed as the mild, modeſt, ſentimental man of gravity, and the bold forward agreeable Rattle of the ladies club; ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Zounds, there's no bearing this; it's worſe than death.

sp.speaker: MISS HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: In which of your characters, ſir, will you give us leave to addreſs you. As the faultering gentleman, with looks on the ground, that ſpeaks juſt to be heard, and hates hypocriſy; or the loud confident creature, that keeps it up with Mrs. Mantrap, and old miſs Biddy Buckſkin, till three in the morning; ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: O, curſe on my noiſy head. I never attempted to be impudent yet, that I was not taken down. I muſt be gone.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: By the hand of my body, but you ſhall not. I ſee it was all a miſtake, and I am rejoiced to find it. You ſhall not, ſir, I tell you. I know ſhe'll forgive you. Won't you forgive him, Kate. We'll all forgive you. Take courage, man. [They retire, ſhe tormenting him to the back ſcene.

sp.speaker: MRS. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: So, ſo, they're gone off. Let them go, I care not.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Who gone?

sp.speaker: MRS. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: My dutiful niece and her gentleman, Mr. Haſtings, from town. He who came down with our modeſt viſitor here.

sp.speaker: SIR CHARLES.
sp.p: Who, my honeſt George Haſtings! As worthy a fellow as lives, and the girl could not have made a more prudent choice.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Then, by the hand of my body, I'm proud of the connexion.

sp.speaker: MRS. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Well, if he has taken away the lady, he has not taken her fortune, that remains in this family to conſole us for her loſs.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Sure Dorothy you would not be ſo mercenary?

sp.speaker: MRS. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Ay, that's my affair, not yours. But you know if your ſon, when of age, refuſes to marry his couſin, her whole fortune is then at her own diſpoſal.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Ay, but he's not of age, and ſhe has not thought proper to wait for his refuſal.

sp.speaker: MRS. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: (Aſide) What, returned ſo ſoon! I begin not to like it.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: (To Hardcaſtle) For my late attempt to fly off with your niece, let my preſent confuſion be my puniſhment. We are now come back, to appeal from your juſtice to your humanity. By her father's conſent, I firſt paid her my addreſſes, and our paſſions were firſt founded in duty.

sp.speaker: MISS NEVILLE.
sp.p: Since his death, I have been obliged to ſtoop to diſſimulation to avoid oppreſſion. In an hour of levity, I was ready even to give up my fortune to ſecure my choice. But I'm now recover'd from the deluſion, and hope from your tenderneſs what is denied me from a nearer connexion.

sp.speaker: MRS. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Pſhaw, pſhaw, this is all but the whining end of a modern novel.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Be it what it will, I'm glad they're come back to reclaim their due. Come hither, Tony boy. Do you refuſe this lady's hand whom I now offer you?

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: What ſignifies my refuſing. You know I can't refuſe her till I'm of age, father.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: While I thought concealing your age, boy, was likely to conduce to your improvement, I concurred with your mother's deſire to keep it ſecret. But ſince I find ſhe turns it to a wrong uſe, I muſt now declare, you have been of age theſe three months.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Of age! Am I of age, father?

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Above three months.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Then you'll ſee the firſt uſe I'll make of my liberty. (taking miſs Neville's hand) Witneſs all men by theſe preſents, that I, Anthony Lumpkin, eſquire, of BLANK place, refuſe you, Conſtantia Neville, ſpinſter, of no place at all, for my true and lawful wife. So Conſtance Neville may marry whom ſhe pleaſes, and Tony Lumpkin is his own man again.

sp.speaker: SIR CHARLES.
sp.p: O brave 'ſquire.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: My worthy friend.

sp.speaker: MRS. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: My undutiful offspring.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Joy, my dear George, I give you joy ſincerely. And could I prevail upon my little tyrant here to be leſs arbitrary, I ſhould be the happieſt man alive, if you would return me the favour.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p:
(To miſs Hardcaſtle) Come, madam, you are now driven to the very laſt ſcene of all your contrivances.
I know you like him, I'm ſure he loves you, and you muſt and ſhall have him.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: (Joining their hunds) And I ſay ſo too. And, Mr. Marlow, if ſhe makes as good a wife as ſhe has a daughter, I don't believe you'll ever repent your bargain. So now to ſupper. To-morrow we ſhall gather all the poor of the pariſh about us, and the miſtakes of the night ſhall be crowned with a merry morning; ſo, boy, take her; and as you have been miſtaken in the miſtreſs, my wiſh is, that you may never be miſtaken in the wife.

lg.l: WELL, having ſtoop'd to conquer with ſucceſs,
And gain'd a huſband without aid from dreſs,
Still as a bar-maid, I could wiſh it too,
As I have conquer'd him to conquer you:
And let me ſay, for all your reſolution,
That pretty bar-maids have done execution.
Our life is all a play, compos'd to pleaſe,
"We have our exits and our entrances."
The firſt act ſhews the ſimple country maid,
Harmleſs and young, of ev'ry thing afraid;
Bluſhes when hir'd, and with unmeaning action,
"I hopes as how to give you ſatisfaction."
Her ſecond act diſplays a livelier ſcene,—
Th' unbluſhing bar-maid of a country inn,
Who whiſks about the houſe, at market caters,
Talks loud, coquets the gueſts, and ſcolds the waiters.
Next the ſcene ſhifts to town, and there ſhe ſoars,
The chop-houſe toaſt of ogling connoiſieurs.
On 'ſquires and cits ſhe there diſplays her arts,
And on the gridiron broils her lover's hearts—
And as ſhe ſmiles, her triumphs to compleat,
Even common councilmen forget to eat.
The fourth act ſhews her wedded to the 'ſquire,
And madam now begins to hold it higher;
Pretends to taſte, at Operas cries caro,
And quits her Nancy Dawſon, for Che Faro.
Doats upon dancing, and in all her pride,
Swims round the room, the Heinel of Cheapſide:
Ogles and leers with artificial ſkill,
Till having loſt in age the power to kill,
She ſits all night at cards, and ogles at ſpadille.
Such, thro' our lives, the eventful hiſtory—
The fifth and laſt act ſtill remains for me.
The bar-maid now for your protection prays,
Turns female Barriſter, and pleads for Bays.

head.hi: TO BE SPOKEN IN THE CHARACTER OF TONY LUMPKIN.This came too late to be ſpoken.

lg.l: WELL—now all's ended—and my comrades gone,
Pray what becomes of mother's nonly ſon?
A hopeful blade!—in town I'll fix my ſtation,
And try to make a bluſter in the nation.
As for my couſin Neville, I renounce her,
Off—in a crack—I'll carry big Bett Bouncer.
Why ſhould not I in the great world appear?
I ſoon ſhall have a thouſand pounds a year;
No matter what a man may here inherit,
In London—'gad, they've ſome regard to ſpirit.
I ſee the horſes prancing up the ſtreets,
And big Bett Bouncer, bobs to all ſhe meets;
Then hoikes to jiggs and paſtimes ev'ry night—
Not to the plays—they ſay it a'n't polite;
To Sadler's-Wells perhaps, or Operas go,
And once by chance, to the roratorio.
Thus here and there, for ever up and down,
We'll ſet the faſhions too, to half the town;
And then at auctions—money ne'er regard,
Buy pictures like the great, ten pounds a yard;
Zounds, we ſhall make theſe London gentry ſay,
We know what's damn'd genteel as well as they.
